{{Infobox Government agency |agency_name = Financial Crimes Enforcement Network |logo = |logo_width = |logo_caption = |seal = US-FinancialCrimesEnforcementNetwork-Seal.svg |seal_width = 160px |seal_caption = |formed = April 25, 1990 |headquarters = [[Vienna, Virginia]] |employees = |budget = |chief1_name = Director |chief1_position = Ken Blanco |parent_agency = [[Office of Terrorism and Financial Intelligence]] |website = {{url|FinCEN.gov|FinCEN.gov}} |footnotes = }} The '''Financial Crimes Enforcement Network''' ('''FinCEN''') is a bureau of the [[United States Department of the Treasury]] that collects and analyzes information about financial transactions in order to combat domestic and international [[money laundering]], [[terrorist financing]], and other [[financial crimes]].
==Mission== FinCEN's director expressed its mission in November 2013 as "to safeguard the financial system from illicit use, combat money laundering and promote national security."<ref name=FinCENDir>{{cite web|last=Shasky Calvery|first=Jennifer|title=Statement of Jennifer Shasky Calvery, Director Financial Crimes Enforcement Network US Department of the Treasury Before the US Senate Committee on Homeland Security and Government Affairs|url=http://www.hsgac.senate.gov/hearings/beyond-silk-road-potential-risks-threats-and-promises-of-virtual-currencies|publisher=Financial Crimes Enforcement Network|accessdate=6 March 2014|date=November 18, 2013}}</ref> FinCEN serves as the U.S. [[Financial Intelligence Unit]] (FIU) and is one of 147 FIUs making up the [[Egmont Group of Financial Intelligence Units]]. FinCEN's self-described motto is "[[follow the money]]." The website states: "The primary motive of criminals is financial gain, and they leave financial trails as they try to launder the proceeds of crimes or attempt to spend their ill-gotten profits."<ref name=what>{{cite web|title=FinCEN - What we do|url=https://www.fincen.gov/what-we-do/|work=FinCEN website|publisher=FinCEN|accessdate=13 November 2016}}</ref> It is a network bringing people and information together, by coordinating [[information sharing]] with law enforcement agencies, regulators and other partners in the [[financial services|financial industry]].<ref name=what/>
==History== FinCEN was established by order of the [[Secretary of the Treasury]] (Treasury Order Numbered 105-08) on April 25, 1990. In May 1994, its mission was broadened to include regulatory responsibilities, and in October 1994 the [[United States Department of the Treasury|Treasury Department]]'s precursor of FinCEN, the Office of Financial Enforcement was merged with FinCEN. On September 26, 2002, after [[Patriot Act, Title III|Title III of the PATRIOT Act]] was passed, Treasury Order 180-01<ref>{{cite web|title=TREASURY ORDER 180-01|url=http://www.treasury.gov/about/role-of-treasury/orders-directives/Pages/to180-01.aspx|publisher=U.S. Dept Treasury|accessdate=6 March 2014|date=March 24, 2003}}</ref> made it an official bureau in the Department of the Treasury. In September 2012, FinCEN's information technology called FinCEN Portal and Query System migrated with 11 years of data into FinCEN Query, a search engine similar to Google. It is a "one stop shop" {{sic}} accessible via the FinCEN Portal allowing broad searches across more fields than before and returning more results. Since September 2012 FinCEN generates 4 new reports: Suspicious Activity Report (FinCEN SAR), Currency Transaction Report (FinCEN CTR), the Designation of Exempt Person (DOEP) and Registered Money Service Business (RMSB).<ref name=FinCEN>{{cite web|title=FinCEN - FinCEN's IT Modernization Efforts FAQs|url=http://www.fincen.gov/about_fincen/wwd/ITModernizationEffortsFAQ.html|work=FinCEN website|publisher=FinCEN|accessdate=6 March 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140217205349/http://www.fincen.gov/about_fincen/wwd/ITModernizationEffortsFAQ.html|archivedate=17 February 2014|df=}}</ref>
==Organization== [[Image:FinCEN organization.jpg|350px|right|thumb|FinCEN organization chart]] As of November 2013, FinCEN employed approximately 340 people mostly intelligence professionals with expertise in the [[financial industry]], illicit finance, [[financial intelligence]], the AML/CFT (money laundering/terrorist financing) regulatory regime, computer technology, and enforcement".<ref name=FinCENDir/> The majority of the staff are permanent FinCEN personnel, with about 20 long-term detailees assigned from 13 different regulatory and law enforcement agencies.<ref name=FinCEN /> FinCEN shares information with dozens of intelligence agencies, including the [[Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, and Firearms]]; the [[Drug Enforcement Administration]]; the [[Federal Bureau of Investigation]]; the [[U.S. Secret Service]]; the [[Internal Revenue Service]]; the [[United States Customs Service|Customs Service]]; and the [[U.S. Postal Inspection Service]].
===FinCEN Directors=== * Brian M. Bruh (1990–1993) * Stanley E. Morris (1994–1998) * [[James F. Sloan]] (April 1999 – October 2003) * William J. Fox (December 2003 – February 2006) * Robert W. Werner (March 2006 – December 2006) * James H. Freis, Jr. (March 2007 – August 2012) * [[Jennifer Shasky Calvery]] (September 2012 – May 2016) * Jamal El-Hindi (Acting, June 2016 – present)<ref>{{cite web|title=FinCEN - What we do|url=https://www.fincen.gov/what-we-do|work=FinCEN website|publisher=FinCEN|accessdate=13 November 2016}}</ref>
==314 program== The 2001 [[USA PATRIOT Act]] required the Secretary of the Treasury to create a secure network for the transmission of information to enforce the relevant regulations. FinCEN's regulations under Section 314(a) enable federal law enforcement agencies, through FinCEN, to reach out to more than 45,000 points of contact at more than 27,000 financial institutions to locate accounts and transactions of persons that may be involved in terrorist financing and/or money laundering. A web interface allows the person(s) designated in §314(a)(3)(A) to register and transmit information to FinCEN. The partnership between the financial community and law enforcement allows disparate bits of information to be identified, centralized, and rapidly evaluated.<ref>{{cite web|title=Appendix A – Financial Crimes enforcement network programs|url=https://www.fincen.gov/news_room/rp/files/Appendix_A.pdf|publisher=FinCEN|accessdate=23 August 2016}}</ref>
==Hawala== As early as 2003 FinCEN disseminated information on "[[informal value transfer system]]s" (IVTS), including [[hawala]], a network of people receiving money for the purpose of making the funds payable to a third party in another geographic location,... generally tak[ing] place outside of the conventional banking system through non-bank financial institutions or other business entities whose primary business activity may not be the transmission of money.<ref>{{cite web|title=Informal Value Transfer Systems|url=http://www.fincen.gov/news_room/rp/advisory/pdf/advis33.pdf|work=Financial Crimes Enforcement Network FinCEN Advisory|publisher=United States Department of the Treasury|accessdate=6 March 2014|format=PDF|date=March 2003|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140630205556/http://www.fincen.gov/news_room/rp/advisory/pdf/advis33.pdf|archivedate=30 June 2014|df=}}</ref> On September 1, 2010, FinCEN issued a guidance on IVTS referencing ''[[United States v. Banki]]'' and hawala.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fincen.gov/statutes_regs/guidance/html/FIN-2010-A011.html|title=Informal Value Transfer Systems|publisher=Financial Crimes Enforcement Network|date=September 1, 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100905002704/http://www.fincen.gov/statutes_regs/guidance/html/FIN-2010-A011.html|archivedate=September 5, 2010|df=}}</ref>
==Virtual currencies== In July 2011, FinCEN added "other value that substitutes for currency" to its definition of [[money services business]]es in preparation to adapt the respective rule to virtual currencies.<ref>{{cite web|title=Financial Crimes Enforcement Network|url=https://federalregister.gov/a/2011-18309|work=Bank Secrecy Act Regulations; Definitions and Other Regulations Relating to Money Services Businesses|publisher=Federal Register|accessdate=6 March 2014|author=Financial Crimes Enforcement Network|page=76 FR 43585|date=2011-07-21|quote=31 C.F.R. § 1010.100(ff)(5)(i)(A)}}</ref> On March 18, 2013 FinCEN issued a guidance regarding [[virtual currency|virtual currencies]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fincen.gov/statutes_regs/guidance/html/FIN-2013-G001.html|title=FIN-2013-G001: Application of FinCEN's Regulations to Persons Administering, Exchanging, or Using Virtual Currencies|date=18 March 2013|publisher=Financial Crimes Enforcement Network|page=6|accessdate=4 March 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130319213642/http://fincen.gov/statutes_regs/guidance/html/FIN-2013-G001.html|archivedate=19 March 2013|df=}}</ref> according to which, exchangers and administrators, but not users of convertible virtual currency are considered money transmitters, and must comply with rules to prevent money laundering/terrorist financing ("AML/CFT") and other forms of financial crime, by record-keeping, reporting and registering with FinCEN. Jennifer Shasky Calvery, director of FinCEN said, "Virtual currencies are subject to the same rules as other currencies. … Basic money services business rules apply here."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.abajournal.com/magazine/article/some_basic_rules_for_using_bitcoin_as_virtual_money/ |title=Some basic rules for using 'bitcoin' as virtual money |publisher=American Bar Association |year=2013 |author=Berson, Susan A.|accessdate=10 September 2013}}</ref>
At a November 2013 [[United States Senate|Senate]] hearing, Calvery stated, "It is in the best interest of virtual currency providers to comply with these regulations for a number of reasons. First is the idea of corporate responsibility," contrasting [[Bitcoin]]'s understanding of a peer to peer system bypassing corporate financial institutions. She stated that FinCEN collaborates with the [[Federal Financial Institutions Examination Council]], a congressionally-chartered forum called the "Bank Secrecy Act (BSA) Advisory Group" and BSA Working Group to review and discuss new regulations and guidance, with the FBI-led "Virtual Currency Emerging Threats Working Group" (VCET) formed in early 2012, the FDIC-led "Cyber Fraud Working Group", the Terrorist Financing & Financial Crimes-led "Treasury Cyber Working Group", and with a community of other financial intelligence units.<ref name="FinCENDir" /> According to the Department of Justice, VCET members represent the FBI, the Drug Enforcement Administration, multiple U.S. Attorney's Offices, and the [[United States Department of Justice Criminal Division|Criminal Division's]] Asset Forfeiture and Money Laundering Section and Computer Crime and Intellectual Property Section.<ref>{{cite web|last=|title=Acting Assistant Attorney General Mythili Raman Testifies|url=http://www.justice.gov/criminal/pr/speeches/2013/crm-speech-131118.html|work=Senate Committee on Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs|publisher=justice.gov|accessdate=6 March 2014|location=Washington, D.C|date=November 18, 2013}}</ref>
==Controversies== In 2009, the [[GAO]] found "opportunities" to improve "interagency and state examination coordination", noting that the federal banking regulators issued an interagency examination manual, that [[U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission|SEC]], [[Commodity Futures Trading Commission|CFTC]], and their respective self-regulatory organizations developed [[Bank Secrecy Act]] (BSA) examination modules, and that FinCEN and [[IRS]] examining nonbank financial institutions issued an examination manual for money services businesses. Therefore multiple regulators examine compliance of the BSA across industries and for some larger holding companies even within the same institution. Regulators need to promote greater consistency, coordination and information-sharing, reduce unnecessary regulatory burden, and find concerns across industries.<ref name=GAO>{{cite web|title=Bank Secrecy Act: Federal Agencies Should Take Action to Further Improve Coordination and Information-Sharing Efforts|url=http://www.gao.gov/products/GAO-09-227|work=GAO-09-227|publisher=GAO.gov|accessdate=6 March 2014|date=Feb 12, 2009}}</ref> FinCEN estimated that it would have data access agreements with 80 percent of state agencies that conduct BSA examinations after 2012.<ref name=GAO />
Since FinCEN's inception in 1990 the [[Electronic Frontier Foundation]] in San Francisco has debated its benefits compared to its threat to privacy.<ref>{{cite web |last=Bercu |first=Stephen |title=FinCEN: Big Brother After All?|url=https://w2.eff.org/Privacy/Surveillance/?f=cpsr_fincen.paper.txt |publisher=EEF.org |date=December 1991}}</ref> FinCEN´s value is hard to gauge without publication of evidence. It does not disclose how many 'Suspicious Activity Reports' result in investigations, indictments or convictions, and no studies exist to tally how many reports are filed on innocent people. FinCEN and money laundering laws have been criticized for being expensive and relatively ineffective, while violating [[Fourth Amendment to the United States Constitution|Fourth Amendment]] rights as an investigator may use FinCEN's government database system to investigate people instead of crimes.<ref>{{cite news|last=|title=Following the Money|url=http://www.govexec.com/magazine/2000/10/following-the-money/7309/ |accessdate=6 March 2014|newspaper=[[Government Executive]] |date=October 1, 2000|author=Julie Wakefield}}</ref>
It has also been alleged, that FinCEN's regulations against [[structuring]] are enforced unfairly and arbitrarily; for example, it was reported in 2012 that small businesses selling at farmers' markets have been targeted, while politically connected people like [[Eliot Spitzer]] were not prosecuted.<ref>{{cite web|author=Walter Olson |url=http://overlawyered.com/2012/04/structuring-who-can-get-away-with-it-and-who-cant/ |title="Structuring": who can get away with it, and who can't |publisher=Overlawyered |date=2012-04-20 |accessdate=2013-11-30}}</ref> Spitzers reasons for structuring were described as "innocent".<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/03/12/nyregion/12legal.html |title=The Reports That Drew Federal Eyes to Spitzer |author=David Johnston |author2=Stephen Labaton |newspaper=The New York Times |date=March 12, 2008}}</ref>
== In popular culture == The 2016 film ''[[The Accountant (2016 film)|The Accountant]]'' features a FinCEN investigation into the title character.<ref>{{Cite web |first=Tish |last=Wells |date=October 15, 2016 |title=Film Review: The Accountant (2016) |url=http://culturedvultures.com/the-accountant-2016-review/ |access-date=November 16, 2016}}</ref>

[[File:James Hope Moulton.png|thumb|James Hope Moulton]] {{Use dmy dates|date=April 2012}} The Reverend '''James Hope Moulton''' (11 October 1863 - 9 April 1917) was a [[United Kingdom|British]] non-conformist divine. He was also a [[philology|philologist]] and made a special study of [[Zoroastrianism]]. [[File:James Hope Moulton Signature.png|thumb|James Hope Moulton Signature]]
==Biography== His family had a strong [[Methodist]] background. His [[William Fiddian Moulton|father]] was the first headmaster of the [[Leys School]], [[Cambridge]] where James was one of the first students. After attending [[King's College, Cambridge]],<ref>{{acad|id=MLTN882JH|name=Moulton, James Hope}}</ref> he chose to become a [[Methodist|Wesleyan]] minister. He showed a strong talent for academic studies, and the [[Victoria University of Manchester|University of Manchester]] invited him to teach [[Ancient Greek language|Classical Greek]] and other languages. He was also teaching at the [[Didsbury College (Methodist)|Didsbury College]], a Methodist seminary near [[Manchester]]. He was a friend of [[James Frazer]], the Scottish [[social anthropologist]].<ref>Frazer, J. (2005) ''Selected Letters of Sir J. G. Frazer''. Oxford University Press</ref> He developed a strong interest in [[Zoroastrianism]], one of the world's oldest known [[monotheistic]] religions. Over the course of his life he published many books and papers, mainly focused on Zoroastrianism and the [[Koine Greek|Greek]] texts that the [[Bible]] is derived from. He was a [[Prison Chaplain]] at [[Preston, Lancashire|Preston]] for some time around 1910.<ref>[http://www.institutions.org.uk/prisons/info/methodist_prison_chaplains.htm Methodist Prison Chaplains<!-- bot-generated title -->] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061108200358/http://www.institutions.org.uk/prisons/info/methodist_prison_chaplains.htm |date=8 November 2006 }} at www.institutions.org.uk</ref>
In 1916 he decided to take advantage of the academic lull of [[World War I]]<ref name="treasure">[https://www.questia.com/PM.qst?a=o&d=1197485 The Treasure of the Magi: A Study of Modern Zoroastrianism<!-- bot-generated title -->] at www.questia.com</ref> and spend a long spell in [[India]], to serve as a Methodist missionary and to research and lecture on [[Zoroastrianism]] in one of its traditional homelands. This was not an easy time for him, as his wife had recently died, and while he was in India, his son William Ralph Osborn Moulton died in the [[France|French]] [[trenches]] on 5 August 1916. He spent 16 months in India under the auspices of the [[YMCA]], researching, preaching and lecturing. A matter that was of particular interest to him was the religion of the [[Parsis]], the Zoroastrians of the Indian subcontinent, and the relationship between their beliefs and [[Judeo-Christian]] religions. He felt that the former was awaiting its completion by the latter.<ref>Moulton, J. (1995). ''The Treasure of the Magi: A Study of Modern Zoroastrianism''. Kessinger Publishing</ref> While in Karachi, he availed of the friendship and library of [[Maneckji Nusserwanji Dhalla]], a U.S.-educated Zoroastrian scholar and the high priest of the Parsi community there.
He left [[Karachi]] aboard the ''[[S.S. City of Paris]]'', headed for [[Egypt]] where he met with his friend and colleague Dr [[J. Rendel Harris]]. The pair set sail from [[Port Said]] but as their ship passed the [[Gulf of Lion]]<!-- singular --> it was torpedoed and sank by a German submarine. Moulton, Harris and several others from the ship escaped in a lifeboat,<ref>Moulton, (1919). '''[https://archive.org/stream/jameshopemoulton00mouluoft/jameshopemoulton00mouluoft_djvu.txt James Hope Moulton]'''. London: Epworth Press</ref> but James Moulton died on the third of the four days it took the boat to reach [[Corsica]], aged fifty-three. He was buried at sea on 9 April 1917.
Almost 3 years previously he opened up his book ''From Egyptian Rubbish Heaps'' with this paragraph "On July 31, 1914, the ill-fated [[RMS Lusitania|Lusitania]] landed at New York after what proved her last peace voyage. A week later two of her passengers proceeded to the Conference at Northfield, where some two thousand Christian people were gathered in sight of the grave of D. L. Moody. It was very hard for us all, doubly hard for Britons, to detach our thoughts even partially from the horrors that were already beginning—horrors which will long make it impossible to name even the best of Germans without a sharp stab of pain. But we were studying the only Book that can ever bring peace and comfort to men in their direst need, and there is no fear that those who know will think we were ‘fiddling while Rome burned.’" He had been aboard the ship on its last voyage just as World War 1 began. It was sunk less than 11 months later killing everyone on board.
==Academic positions== * Tutor at [[Didsbury College (Methodist)|Didsbury College]]<ref>[http://www.abcog.org/moulton1.htm James Hope Moulton: Egyptian Rubbish-Heaps and the Study of the New Testament<!-- bot-generated title -->] at www.abcog.org</ref> * [[Fellow]] of [[King's College, Cambridge]]<ref name=treasure/> * Greenwood Professor of [[Hellenistic Greek]] and [[Indo-European languages|Indo-European Philology]] at [[Victoria University of Manchester|Manchester University]],<ref name=treasure/> 1908-17<ref>Charlton, H. B. (1951) ''Portrait of a University, 1851-1951''. Manchester: Manchester University Press; p. 171</ref> * [[Doctor of Letters]] (D. Litt.), [[University of London]], 19 December 1901<ref>{{Cite newspaper The Times |articlename=University intelligence |day_of_week=Friday |date=20 December 1901 |page_number=8 |issue=36643| }}</ref>
==Works== * ''Grammar of New Testament Greek Vol. I - Prolegomena'', '''1906''' * ''WILLIAM F. MOULTON a memoir'', written with his brother, who had the same name as their father, [[William Fiddian Moulton]]<ref>[http://www.abbeybook.com/entries/A59771.html Book A59771 - Moulton, W. Fiddian & James Hope Moulton - WILLIAM F. MOULTON a memoir - 1899<!-- bot-generated title -->] at www.abbeybook.com</ref> * ''The Papers of [[Oscar Browning]]'', written with his father, [[William Fiddian Moulton]]<ref>[http://janus.lib.cam.ac.uk/db/node.xsp?id=EAD%2FGBR%2F0272%2FPP%2FOB%2F1%2F1157%2FA Janus: The Papers of Oscar Browning<!-- bot-generated title -->] at janus.lib.cam.ac.uk</ref> * ''Early Religious Poetry of Persia'' * ''Early Religious Poetry of Persia, 1911'' * ''From Egyptian Rubbish Heaps, 1916 (second edition 1917)'' * ''Early Zoroastrianism'' * ''Fire Temples and Towers of Silence'' * ''Parsi Piety'' * ''The Crown of Zoroastrianism'' * ''The Parsis'' * ''The Parsis and Christian Propaganda'' * ''The Teaching of Zarathushtra'' * ''Treasure of the Magi: a study of modern Zoroastrianism'' * ''Zarathustra and the Outside World'' * ''Zoroastrianism'' * ''An Introduction to the Study of New Testament Greek'' (1895) * ''Two Lectures on the Science of Language'' (1903) * ''The Christian Religion in the Study and the Street'' (1919) * ''A Neglected Sacrament and Other Sermons and Addresses'' (1919)
==See also== * [[William Fiddian Moulton]], father * [[John Fletcher Moulton]], uncle * [[Richard Green Moulton]], uncle * [[James Egan Moulton]], uncle * [[George Milligan (moderator)|George Milligan]], co-author of ''Vocabulary of the Greek Testament''.
==References== {{reflist}} * Church History Institute [https://archive.is/20050408173109/http://chi.gospelcom.net/DAILYF/2002/10/daily-10-11-2002.shtml] * Foreword to The Treasure of the Magi: A Study of Modern Zoroastrianism [https://www.questia.com/PM.qst?a=o&d=1197485] * theology today book review [http://theologytoday.ptsem.edu/jul1964/v21-2-bookreview3.htm] * kingkong Author Anniversary database [http://www.kingkong.demon.co.uk/ngcoba/mo4.htm]
==External links== * ''From Egyptian Rubbish Heaps'', Transcripts of a series of lectures he gave in 1914 [http://www.abcog.org/moulton1.htm] * Online transcript of ''The Treasure of the Magi: A Study of Modern Zoroastrianism''[https://www.questia.com/PM.qst?a=o&d=1197481]
{{Authority control}}

[[File:Christ teacher.jpg|thumb|240px|Early Christian [[Catacombs of Rome|Catacomb]] painting of Jesus and his disciples, pre-third century.]] There are several references in the [[Synoptic Gospels]] (the gospels of [[Gospel of Matthew|Matthew]], [[Gospel of Mark|Mark]] and [[Gospel of Luke|Luke]]) to [[Jesus]] '''predicting his own death''', the first two occasions building up to the final prediction of [[Crucifixion of Jesus|his crucifixion]].''St Mark's Gospel and the Christian faith'' by Michael Keene 2002 {{ISBN|0-7487-6775-4}} pages 24-25 Matthew's Gospel adds a prediction, before he and his [[Disciple (Christianity)|disciple]]s enter [[Jerusalem]], that he will be crucified there.''The Temptations of Jesus in Mark's Gospel'' by Susan R. Garrett 1996 {{ISBN|978-0-8028-4259-6}} pages 74-75 In the [[Gospel of Mark]], generally agreed to be the earliest Gospel, written around the year 70,{{sfnp|Witherington|2001|p=31|ps=: 'from 66 to 70, and probably closer to the latter'}}{{sfnp|Hooker|1991|p=8|ps=: 'the Gospel is usually dated between AD 65 and 75.'}} Jesus predicts his death three times. Walter Schmithals, noting that this Gospel also contains verses in which Jesus appears to predict his [[Passion (Christianity)|Passion]], suggests that these represent the earlier traditions available to the author, and the three death predictions are redactional creations of the author.Walter Schmithals, ''The Theology of the First Christians'' (Westminster John Knox Press, 1997) page 22. The setting for the first prediction is somewhere near [[Caesarea Philippi]], immediately after [[Apostle Peter|Peter]] proclaims Jesus as the Messiah. Jesus tells his followers that "the [[Son of man (Christianity)|Son of Man]] must suffer many things and be rejected by the elders, chief priests and teachers of the law, and that he must be killed and after three days rise again".''The Gospel according to Mark: meaning and message'' by George Martin 2005 {{ISBN|0-8294-1970-5}} pages 200-202 When Peter objects, Jesus tells him: "Get behind me, Satan! You do not have in mind the things of God, but the things of men". ({{bibleverse||Mark|8:31–33|NRSV}}) The Gospel of {{bibleverse||Matthew|16:21–28|NRSV}} includes this episode,''Matthew for Everyone: Chapters 16-28'' by Tom Wright 2004 {{ISBN|0-664-22787-2}} page 9 saying that Jesus "from that time", i.e. on a number of occasions, Jesus "began to show his disciples that he must go to Jerusalem and suffer many things from the elders and chief priests and scribes, and be killed ...".{{bibleverse||Matthew|16:21|ESV}} The Gospel of {{bibleverse||Luke|9:22–27|NRSV}} shortens the account, dropping the dialogue between Jesus and Peter. Each time Jesus predicts [[Passion of Jesus|his arrest and death]], the disciples in some way or another manifest their incomprehension, and Jesus uses the occasion to teach them new things.''Mercer Dictionary of the Bible'' by Watson E. Mills, Roger Aubrey Bullard 1998 {{ISBN|0-86554-373-9}} page 550 The second warning appears in {{bibleverse||Mark|9:30–32|NIV}} (and also in {{bibleverse||Matthew|17:22–23|NIV}}) as follows:
He said to them, "The Son of Man is going to be betrayed into the hands of men. They will kill him, and after three days he will rise." But they did not understand what he meant and were afraid to ask him about it.{{cite web|url=http://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=mark%209:30-9:32&version=NRSV|title=Bible Gateway passage: Mark 9:30-32 - New Revised Standard Version|publisher=}}
The third prediction in the {{bibleverse||Matthew|20:17–19|NIV}} specifically mentions crucifixion:
Now as Jesus was going up to Jerusalem, he took the twelve disciples aside and said to them, "We are going up to Jerusalem, and the Son of Man will be betrayed to the chief priests and the teachers of the law. They will condemn him to death and will turn him over to the Gentiles to be mocked and flogged and crucified. On the third day he will be raised to life!"{{cite web|url=http://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=matthew%2020:17-20:19&version=NIV|title=Bible Gateway passage: Matthew 20:17-19 - New International Version|publisher=}}
The fourth prediction in Matthew is found in Matthew 26:1-2 immediately precedes the plot made against him by the religious Jewish leaders: "As you know, the Passover is two days away—and the Son of Man will be handed over to be crucified." The hypothetical [[Q source]], widely considered by scholars to be a collection of sayings of Jesus used, in addition to the Gospel of Mark, by the authors of the Luke and Matthew Gospels, contains no predictions of the death of Jesus.John S Kloppenborg, ''Q, the Earliest Gospel'' (Westminster John Knox Press, 2008) page 75. The [[Gospel of John]], in chapters 12 to 17, also mentions several occasions where Jesus prepared his disciples for his departure, which the gospel also refers to as his "glorification":''Dictionary of biblical imagery'' by Leland Ryken, Jim Wilhoit, Tremper Longman, Colin Duriez, Douglas Penney, Daniel G. Reid 1998 {{ISBN|0-8308-1451-5}} page 269
Jesus answered them, saying, “The hour has come that the [[Son of Man]] should be glorified. Most assuredly, I say to you, unless a grain of [[wheat]] falls into the ground and dies, it remains alone; but if it dies, it produces much grain.{{bibleverse|John|12:23-24|NKJV}}
Each of the [[Synoptic Gospels]] refers more times Jesus foretelling His death and resurrection after three days. The [[Bible concordance|concordances]] are summarized in the following table: {| class="wikitable" style="background: #ffffff;" |- ! style="width:20%;background: #ffdead;"| [[Gospel of Matthew|Matthew]] !! style="width:20%;background: #ffdead;"| [[Gospel of Mark|Mark]] !! style="width:20%;background: #ffdead;"| [[Gospel of Luke|Luke]] |- valign="top" | ''[[Matthew 16|Matthew 16:21-23]]'': From that time Jesus began to show to His disciples that He must go to Jerusalem, and suffer many things from the elders and chief priests and scribes, and be killed, and be raised the third day. Then Peter took Him aside and began to rebuke Him, saying, “Far be it from You, Lord; this shall not happen to You!” But He turned and said to Peter, “Get behind Me, Satan! You are an offense to Me, for you are not mindful of the things of God, but the things of men.”{{Bibleref2|Matthew|16:21-23|NKJV|}} || ''[[Mark 8|Mark 8:31-33]]'': And He began to teach them that the Son of Man must suffer many things, and be rejected by the elders and chief priests and scribes, and be killed, and after three days rise again. He spoke this word openly. Then Peter took Him aside and began to rebuke Him. But when He had turned around and looked at His disciples, He rebuked Peter, saying, “Get behind Me, Satan! For you are not mindful of the things of God, but the things of men.”{{Bibleref2|Mark|8:31-33|NKJV|}} || ''[[Luke 9|Luke 9:21-22]]'': And He strictly warned and commanded them to tell this to no one, saying, “The Son of Man must suffer many things, and be rejected by the elders and chief priests and scribes, and be killed, and be raised the third day.”{{Bibleref2|Luke|9:21-22|NKJV|}} |- valign="top" | ''[[Matthew 17|Matthew 17:22-23]]'': Now while they were staying in Galilee, Jesus said to them, “The Son of Man is about to be betrayed into the hands of men, and they will kill Him, and the third day He will be raised up.” And they were exceedingly sorrowful.{{Bibleref2|Matthew|17:22-23|NKJV|}} || ''[[Mark 9|Mark 9:30-32]]'': Then they departed from there and passed through Galilee, and He did not want anyone to know it. For He taught His disciples and said to them, “The Son of Man is being betrayed into the hands of men, and they will kill Him. And after He is killed, He will rise the third day.” But they did not understand this saying, and were afraid to ask Him.{{Bibleref2|Mark|9:30-32|NKJV|}} || ''[[Luke 9|Luke 9:43-45]]'': But while everyone marveled at all the things which Jesus did, He said to His disciples, “Let these words sink down into your ears, for the Son of Man is about to be betrayed into the hands of men.” But they did not understand this saying, and it was hidden from them so that they did not perceive it; and they were afraid to ask Him about this saying.{{Bibleref2|Luke|9:43-45|NKJV|}} |- valign="top" | ''[[Matthew 20|Matthew 20:17-19]]'': Now Jesus, going up to Jerusalem, took the twelve disciples aside on the road and said to them, “Behold, we are going up to Jerusalem, and the Son of Man will be betrayed to the chief priests and to the scribes; and they will condemn Him to death, and deliver Him to the Gentiles to mock and to scourge and to crucify. And the third day He will rise again.” {{Bibleref2|Matthew|20:17-19|NKJV|}} || ''[[Mark 10|Mark 10:32-34]]'': Now they were on the road, going up to Jerusalem, and Jesus was going before them; and they were amazed. And as they followed they were afraid. Then He took the twelve aside again and began to tell them the things that would happen to Him: “Behold, we are going up to Jerusalem, and the Son of Man will be betrayed to the chief priests and to the scribes; and they will condemn Him to death and deliver Him to the Gentiles; and they will mock Him, and [a]scourge Him, and spit on Him, and kill Him. And the third day He will rise again{{Bibleref2|Mark|10:32-34|NKJV|}} || ''[[Luke 18|Luke 18:31-34]]'': Then He took the twelve aside and said to them, “Behold, we are going up to Jerusalem, and all things that are written by the prophets concerning the Son of Man will be accomplished. For He will be delivered to the Gentiles and will be mocked and insulted and spit upon. They will scourge Him and kill Him. And the third day He will rise again.” But they understood none of these things; this saying was hidden from them, and they did not know the things which were spoken.{{Bibleref2|Luke|18:31-34|NKJV|}} |- valign="top" |} As shown in the Daily Mass Readings provided in the Latin Rite of the Roman Catholic Church{{cite web | url = http://www.ewtn.com/daily-readings/?date=2018-9-23 | title = Daily Mass Readings - 23 September 2018 – Sunday | language = en | website = catholiewtn.com| archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20181121203524/http://www.ewtn.com/daily-readings/?date=2018-9-23 | archive-date = Nov 21, 2018 | deadurl = no}}, the prediction given by Jesus in [[Gospel of Mark#Predictions about the crucifixion|Mark 9:32]] has one of its main [[Bible concordance|references]] in the [[Book of Wisdom#Themes|Wisdom of ''Solomon'']]{{cite web | url = https://www.kingjamesbibleonline.org/Wisdom-of-Solomon-Chapter-2_Original-1611-KJV/ | title = The 1611 King James Bible. Book of Wisdom, chapter, vv. 12, and 17 to 20 | website = kingjamesbibleonline.org | language = en | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20120628180442/https://www.kingjamesbibleonline.org/Wisdom-of-Solomon-Chapter-2_Original-1611-KJV/ | archive-date = Jun 28, 2012 | deadurl = no}}: {{quote|12 Therefore let us lie in wait for the righteous; because he is not for our turn, and he is clean contrary to our doings: he upbraideth us with our offending the law, and objecteth to our infamy the transgressings of our education. 17 Let us see if his words be true: and let us prove what shall happen in the end of him. For if the just man be the son of God, he will help him, and deliver him from the hand of his enemies. Let us examine him with despitefulness and torture, that we may know his meekness, and prove his patience. Let us condemn him with a shameful death: for by his own saying he shall be respected.|Book of Wisdom 2:12, 17-20 (KJV translation)}} ==See also== * [[Chronology of Jesus]] * [[Jesus predicts his betrayal]] * [[Life of Jesus in the New Testament]] ==Notes== {{Reflist}} ==References== ;Books {{refbegin|2}} *{{cite book |last=Barclay |first=William |authorlink=William Barclay (theologian) |title=The Gospel of John, Volume 1 |year=2001 |url=https://books.google.com/books?isbn=066422489X |isbn=9780664237806 |publisher=Westminster John Knox Press |ref=harv}} *{{cite book |last=Davies |first=Stevan L. |title=The Gospel of Thomas and Christian Wisdom |year=2004 |publisher=Bardic Press |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=4pifdYcwcbcC |isbn=9780974566740 |ref=harv}} *{{cite book |last=Fitzmyer |first=Joseph A. |authorlink=Joseph Fitzmyer |title=The Gospel According to Luke, X-XXIV |year=1985 |publisher=Doubleday |series=[[Anchor Bible Series|The Anchor Bible Reference Library]] |isbn=9780300139815 |ref=harv}} *{{cite book |last=Harrington |first=Daniel J. |authorlink=Daniel J. Harrington |title=The Gospel of Matthew |year=1991 |publisher=Liturgical Press |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=bNf13S3k2w0C |isbn=9780814658031 |ref=harv}} *{{cite book |last=Hooker |first=Morna |authorlink=Morna Hooker |title=The Gospel According to Saint Mark |year=1991 |publisher=Continuum |url=https://books.google.com/books?isbn=0826460399 |isbn=9780826460394 |ref=harv}} *{{cite book |last=Witherington |first=Ben |authorlink=Ben Witherington III |title=The Gospel of Mark: A Socio-Rhetorical Commentary |year=2001 |publisher=Eerdmans Publishing |url=https://books.google.com/books?isbn=0802845037 |isbn=9780802845030 |ref=harv}} {{refend}} [[Category:Gospel episodes]] [[Category:Crucifixion of Jesus]] [[Category:Death predictions]]

{{redirect|Death by a thousand cuts}} {{italic}} {{Use dmy dates|date=May 2012}} [[File:Martyrerp 2.jpg|thumb|350px|An 1858 illustration from the French newspaper ''[[Le Monde illustré]]'', of the ''lingchi'' execution of a French missionary, [[Auguste Chapdelaine]], in China. Actually, Chapdelaine died from physical abuse in prison, and was beheaded after death.]] {{infobox Chinese |title=''Lingchi'' |pic=Lingchi (Chinese characters).svg |piccap="''Lingchi'' in Traditional (top) and Simplified (bottom) Chinese characters |picupright=0.375 |t=凌遲 |s=凌迟 |p=língchí |w=ling<sup>2</sup>-ch'ih<sup>2</sup> |mi={{IPAc-cmn|l|ing|2|.|ch|^|2}} |j=ling<sup>4</sup>-ci<sup>4</sup> |y=lìhng-chìh |ci={{IPAc-yue|l|ing|4|.|c|i|4}} |tl=lêng-tî }} '''''Lingchi''''' ({{zh|t=凌遲}}), translated variously as the '''slow process''', the '''lingering death''', or '''slow slicing''', and also known as '''death by a thousand cuts''', was a form of torture and [[execution]] used in [[China]] from roughly 900 CE until it was banned in 1905. It was also used in [[Vietnam]]. In this form of execution, a knife was used to methodically remove portions of the body over an extended period of time, eventually resulting in death.
''Lingchi'' was reserved for crimes viewed as especially severe, such as treason. Some Westerners were executed in this manner. Even after the practice was outlawed, the concept itself has still appeared across many types of media.
== Etymology == The term ''lingchi'' first appeared in a line in Chapter 28 of the classical philosophical text ''[[Xunzi (book)|Xunzi]]''. The line originally described the difficulty in travelling in a horse-drawn carriage on mountainous terrain.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Xun|first1=Kuang|authorlink1=Xun Kuang|title=Xunzi|date=3rd century BCE|location=China|chapter=28|quote=三尺之岸而虛車不能登也，百仞之山任負車登焉，何則？陵遲故也。|url=http://ctext.org/xunzi/you-zuo}}</ref> Later on, it was used to describe the prolonging of a person's agony when the person is being killed.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Shen|first1=Jiaben|title=历代刑法考 [Research on Judicial Punishments over the Dynasties]|date=2006|publisher=[[Zhonghua Book Company]]|location=China|isbn=9787101014631|url=https://book.douban.com/subject/1944166/|language=Chinese}}</ref>
==Description== The process involved tying the condemned prisoner to a wooden frame, usually in a public place. The flesh was then cut from the body in multiple slices in a process that was not specified in detail in Chinese law, and therefore most likely varied. The punishment worked on three levels: as a form of public humiliation, as a slow and lingering death, and as a punishment after death.
According to the [[Confucianism|Confucian]] principle of [[filial piety]], to alter one's body or to cut the body are considered unfilial practices. ''Lingchi'' therefore contravenes the demands of filial piety. In addition, to be cut to pieces meant that the body of the victim would not be "whole" in spiritual life after death. This method of execution became a fixture in the image of China among some Westerners.<ref>{{Citation|last=Morrison|first=JM|title=Twentieth Century: The History of the World, 1901 to 2000|year=2000}}.</ref>
''Lingchi'' could be used for the torture and execution of a living person, or applied as an act of humiliation after death. It was meted out for major offences such as [[high treason]], [[mass murder]], [[patricide]]/[[matricide]] or the murder of one's master or employer.<ref>{{cite web|script-title=zh:清李毓昌命案 于保业|trans-title=The Qing Dynasty Case of Li Yuchang|url=http://www.jimo.gov.cn/jmwenhuaju/inc/list.asp?id=16991&webid=171|language=Chinese|date=2006|location=[[Jimo]]|publisher=Jimo Cultural Network|accessdate=25 May 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120805150939/http://www.jimo.gov.cn/jmwenhuaju/inc/list.asp?id=16991&webid=171|archivedate=5 August 2012|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Emperors used it to threaten people and sometimes ordered it for minor offences.<ref>[[Hongwu Emperor]]. ''大誥'' [''Letters Patent'']</ref><ref>文秉 [Wen Bing]. ''先撥志始'' [Volume One of the History]</ref> There were forced convictions and wrongful executions.<ref>王世貞 [Shizhen (1526–90)]. ''弇山堂别集'' [''Yanshan Hall Collection''], vol. 97</ref><ref>劉若愚 [Liu Ruoyu (1584–?)]. ''酌中志'' [Discretion in Chi], vol. 2</ref> Some emperors meted out this punishment to the family members of their enemies.<ref>{{cite journal|title=沈万三家族覆灭记 |trans-title=Destruction of the Shen Manzo family |url=http://www.0512yy.com/showart.asp?id=3324 |date=25 May 2007 |journal=Suzhou Magazine (苏州杂志) |language=Chinese |issn=1005-1651 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151227045456/http://www.0512yy.com/showart.asp?id=3324 |archivedate=27 December 2015 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite book|author=Gu Yingtai (谷應泰) (1620–90)|title=明史紀事本末|trans-title=Major Events in Ming History|volume=18 |language=Chinese}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|title=國朝典故·立閑齋錄|trans-title=Ming Dynasty History|language=Chinese}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=太平天國.1|trans-title=Taiping.1|url=http://blog.udn.com/joeee3/3718452|date=25 January 2010|website=[[United Daily News|UDN]]|language=Chinese|access-date=27 December 2015}}</ref>
While it is difficult to obtain accurate details of how the executions took place, they generally consisted of cuts to the arms, legs, and chest leading to amputation of limbs, followed by decapitation or a stab to the heart. If the crime was less serious or the executioner merciful, the first cut would be to the throat causing death; subsequent cuts served solely to dismember the corpse.
Art historian [[James Elkins (art critic)|James Elkins]] argues that extant photos of the execution clearly show that the "death by division" (as it was termed by German criminologist {{Interlanguage link multi|Robert Heindl|de}}) involved some degree of [[dismemberment]] while the subject was living.<ref>Elkins, James, ''The Object Stares Back: On the Nature of Seeing'', New York: Simon and Schuster, 1996</ref> Elkins also argues that, contrary to the apocryphal version of "death by a thousand cuts", the actual process could not have lasted long. The condemned individual is not likely to have remained conscious and aware (if even alive) after one or two severe wounds, so the entire process could not have included more than a "few dozen" wounds.
In the [[Yuan dynasty]], 100 cuts were inflicted<ref>[[Guan Hanqing|Guan, Hanqing]]. ''[[The Injustice to Dou E]]''.</ref> but by the [[Ming dynasty]] there were records of 3,000 incisions.<ref>Deng, Zhicheng (鄧之誠). ''Gu Dong Xu Ji'' (骨董續記), vol. 2.</ref><ref>''Yu Qiao Hua Zheng Ben Mo'' (漁樵話鄭本末)</ref> It is described as a fast process lasting no longer than 15 to 20 minutes.<ref name=Bourgon2004ID248CF2Fa2>{{cite web|editor-last=Bourgon|editor-first=Jérôme |last1=Bourgon|first1=Jérôme|last2=Detrie|first2=Muriel|last3=Poulet|first3=Regis|title=Execution in Canton|url=http://turandot.chineselegalculture.org/Textual.php?ID=248&CF=2&Fa=2|date=2004|website=Chinese Torture - Supplices Chinois|publisher=IAO: Institut d'Asie Orientale|language=English, French|accessdate=25 May 2015}}</ref> Available photographic records<ref name=Bourgon2004ID1>{{cite web|editor-last=Bourgon|editor-first=Jérôme|title=Execution of Fu-zhu-li|url=http://turandot.chineselegalculture.org/Event.php?ID=1|date=2004|website=Chinese Torture - Supplices Chinois|publisher=IAO: Institut d'Asie Orientale|language=English, French|accessdate=25 May 2015}}</ref><ref name=Bourgon2004ID8/> seem to prove the speed of the event as the crowd remains consistent across the series of photographs. Moreover, these photographs show a striking contrast between the stream of blood that soaks the left flank of the victim and the lack of blood on the right side, possibly showing that the first or the second cut has reached the heart.<ref>{{Citation|url=http://turandot.chineselegalculture.org/Photographs.php?ID=39|title=Lingchi C, 2nd cut (a)|date=10 April 1905|publisher=CNRS}}.</ref><ref>{{Citation|publisher=CNRS|title=Lingchi A, 2nd cut (breasts)|date=31 October 1904|url=http://turandot.chineselegalculture.org/Photographs.php?ID=130}}.</ref> The ''[[coup de grâce]]'' was all the more certain when the family could afford a bribe to have a stab to the heart inflicted first.<ref>{{cite web |title=狱中杂记 |trans-title=Miscellaneous Records from Prison |url=http://www.ndcnc.gov.cn/datalib/2003/Literature/DL/DL-174122 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20070621221957/http://www.ndcnc.gov.cn/datalib/2003/Literature/DL/DL-174122 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2007-06-21 |website=National Digital Cultural Network |language=Chinese}}</ref> Some emperors ordered three days of cutting<ref>Shen, Defu (沈德符). ''Wan Li Ye Huo Bian'' (萬曆野獲編), vol. 28.</ref><ref>Zhang, Wenlin (張文麟). ''Duan Yan Gong Nian Pu'' (端巖公年譜).</ref> while others may have ordered specific tortures before the execution,<ref>[http://dspace.xmu.edu.cn/dspace/bitstream/2288/20359/1/1815%E5%B9%B4%E5%8F%B0%E6%B9%BE%E7%B1%8D%E5%A4%AA%E7%9B%91%E6%9E%97%E8%A1%A8%E4%B9%8B%E6%AD%BB.pdf Death of the Taiwanese eunuch Lin Biao (台湾籍太监林表之死)]{{dead link|date=May 2012}}</ref> or a longer execution.<ref>Yanbei Laoren (燕北老人). ''Qingdai Shisan Chao Gongwei Mishi'' (清代十三朝宫闱秘史).</ref><ref>Xu, Ke (徐珂). ''Qing Bai Lei Chao'' (清稗類鈔).</ref><ref>[http://lin61930726.pixnet.net/blog/post/30987636 Lingchi - The Most Dreaded Form of Execution (Enter with Caution) (「凌遲」最駭人的死刑5 (慎入))] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100425065529/http://lin61930726.pixnet.net/blog/post/30987636 |date=25 April 2010 }}. Pixnet (22 April 2010). Retrieved 20 May 2012.</ref> For example, records showed that during [[Yuan Chonghuan]]'s execution, Yuan was heard shouting for half a day before his death.<ref>Ji, Liuqi (計六奇). ''Ming Ji Bei Lue'' (明季北略), vol. 5.</ref>
The flesh of the victims may also have been sold as medicine.<ref>Ji, Liuqi (計六奇). ''Ming Ji Bei Lue'' (明季北略), vol. 15.</ref> As an official punishment, death by slicing may also have involved slicing the bones, cremation, and scattering of the deceased's ashes.
==Western perceptions== The Western perception of ''lingchi'' has often differed considerably from the actual practice, and some misconceptions persist to the present. The distinction between the sensationalised Western myth and the Chinese reality was noted by Westerners as early as 1895. That year, Australian traveller [[George Ernest Morrison]], who claimed to have witnessed an execution by slicing, wrote that "''lingchi'' [was] commonly, and quite wrongly, translated as 'death by slicing into 10,000 pieces' — a truly awful description of a punishment whose cruelty has been extraordinarily misrepresented... The mutilation is ghastly and excites our horror as an example of barbarian cruelty; but it is not cruel, and need not excite our horror, since the mutilation is done, not before death, but after."<ref>{{cite web|editor1-first=Jerome|editor1-last=Bourgon|editor2-first=Muriel|editor2-last=Detrie|editor3-first=Regis|editor3-last=Poulet|url=http://turandot.chineselegalculture.org/Textual.php?ID=167&CF=2&Fa=2|last=Morrison|first=George Ernest|publisher=CNRS|location=Lyon, FR|title=Turandot|accessdate=30 July 2009}}</ref>
According to apocryphal lore, ''lingchi'' began when the torturer, wielding an extremely sharp knife, began by putting out the eyes, rendering the condemned incapable of seeing the remainder of the torture and, presumably, adding considerably to the psychological terror of the procedure. Successive rather minor cuts chopped off ears, nose, tongue, fingers, toes and genitals before proceeding to cuts that removed large portions of flesh from more sizable parts, e.g., thighs and shoulders.
The entire process was said to last three days, and to total 3,600 cuts. The heavily carved bodies of the deceased were then put on a parade for a show in the public.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.manchestereventsguide.co.uk/feature/Death_by_a_Thousand_Cuts_at_Chinese_Arts_Centre_18th_January_to_23rd_March/114.html|title=Death by a Thousand Cuts at Chinese Arts Centre 18th January to 23rd March|publisher=Manchester events guide|accessdate=2009-07-30|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090418031632/http://www.manchestereventsguide.co.uk/feature/Death_by_a_Thousand_Cuts_at_Chinese_Arts_Centre_18th_January_to_23rd_March/114.html|archive-date=18 April 2009|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Some victims were reportedly given doses of [[opium]] to alleviate suffering.{{citation needed|date=January 2016}}
[[John Roberts (historian)|John Morris Roberts]], in ''Twentieth Century: The History of the World, 1901 to 2000'' (2000), writes "the traditional punishment of death by slicing... became part of the western image of Chinese backwardness as the 'death of a thousand cuts.'" Roberts then notes that slicing "was ordered, in fact, for [[Kang Youwei|K'ang Yu-Wei]], a man termed the '[[Jean-Jacques Rousseau|Rousseau]] of China', and a major advocate of intellectual and government reform in the 1890s."<ref>Roberts, p. 60, footnote 8.</ref>
Although officially outlawed by the government of the [[Qing dynasty]] in 1905,<ref>{{Cite journal|url=http://journals.cambridge.org/action/displayAbstract?fromPage=online&aid=181371|title=Abolishing 'Cruel Punishments': A Reappraisal of the Chinese Roots and Long-term Efficiency of the Xinzheng Legal Reforms|journal=Modern Asian Studies|volume=37|issue=4|pages=851–862|date=8 October 2003|accessdate=30 July 2009|doi=10.1017/S0026749X03004050|last1=Bourgon|first1=Jérôme}}</ref> ''lingchi'' became a widespread Western symbol of the Chinese penal system from the 1910s on, and in [[Zhao Erfeng]]'s administration.<ref>{{Citation|url=http://www.phayl.com/news/article.aspx?id=24749|title=From Darkness to Dawn|first=Jamyang|last=Norbu|author-link=Jamyang Norbu|publisher=Phayl}}{{Dead link|date=October 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> Three sets of photographs shot by French soldiers in 1904–05 were the basis for later mythification. The abolition was immediately enforced, and definite: no official sentences of ''lingchi'' were performed in China after April 1905.
Regarding the use of opium, as related in the introduction to Morrison's book, [[Meyrick Hewlett]] insisted that "most Chinese people sentenced to death were given large quantities of opium before execution, and Morrison avers that a charitable person would be permitted to push opium into the mouth of someone dying in agony, thus hastening the moment of decease." At the very least, such tales were deemed credible to British officials in China and other Western observers.
==History== [[File:Martyrdom of Joseph Marchand.jpg|thumb|upright=1|left|Execution of [[Joseph Marchand]] in Vietnam, 1835.]]
''Lingchi'' existed under the earliest emperors,{{citation needed|date=May 2015}} although similar but less cruel tortures were often prescribed instead. Under the reign of [[Qin Er Shi]], the second emperor of the [[Qin dynasty]], multiple tortures were used to punish officials.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Sima|first1=Qian|authorlink1=Sima Qian|title=Records of the Grand Historian|date=91 BCE|location=China|language=Chinese|chapter=87|title-link=Records of the Grand Historian}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Ban|first1=Gu|authorlink1=Ban Gu|title=Book of Han|date=82 CE|language=Chinese|chapter=23|title-link=Book of Han}}</ref>{{clarify|date=March 2015|reason=can't determine if this amounted to lesser torture or worse}} The arbitrary, cruel, and short-lived [[Liu Ziye]] was apt to kill innocent officials by ''lingchi''.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Shen|first1=Yue|authorlink1=Shen Yue|title=Book of Song|date=488 CE|location=China|language=Chinese|chapter=9|title-link=Book of Song}}</ref> [[Emperor Wenxuan of Northern Qi|Gao Yang]] killed only six people by this method,<ref>{{cite book|last1=Li|first1=Baiyao|authorlink1=Li Baiyao|title=Book of Northern Qi|date=636 CE|location=China|language=Chinese|chapter=3|title-link=Book of Northern Qi}}</ref> and [[An Lushan]] killed only one man.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Ouyang|first1=Xiu|authorlink1=Ouyang Xiu|title=New Book of Tang|date=1060 CE|location=China|language=Chinese|chapter=215|title-link=New Book of Tang}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=中國歷史上幾次最著名的凌遲之刑|trans-title=Several of the Most Famous Lingchi Cases in Chinese History|url=http://books.sina.com/artbook/exposure/2008-07-03/ba14878.shtml|date=2008|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090801021147/http://books.sina.com/artbook/exposure/2008-07-03/ba14878.shtml|archive-date=1 August 2009 |website=[[Sina Corp|Sina]]|language=Chinese|access-date=11 October 2015}}</ref> ''Lingchi'' was known in the [[Five Dynasties]] period (907–960 CE); but, in one of the earliest such acts, [[Shi Jingtang]] abolished it.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Xue|first1=Juzheng|authorlink1=Xue Juzheng|title=Old History of the Five Dynasties|date=974 CE|location=China|language=Chinese|chapter=147|title-link=Old History of the Five Dynasties}}</ref> Other rulers continued to use it.
The method was prescribed in the [[Liao dynasty]] law codes,<ref>{{cite book|author=Toqto'a|authorlink1=Toqto'a (Yuan dynasty)|title=History of Liao|date=1344|location=China|language=Chinese|chapter=61|title-link=History of Liao}}</ref> and was sometimes used.<ref>{{cite book|author=Toqto'a|authorlink1=Toqto'a (Yuan dynasty)|title=History of Liao|date=1344|location=China|language=Chinese|chapter=112-114|title-link=History of Liao}}</ref> [[Emperor Tianzuo of Liao|Emperor Tianzuo]] often executed people in this way during his rule.<ref>{{cite book|author=Toqto'a|authorlink1=Toqto'a (Yuan dynasty)|title=History of Liao|date=1344|location=China|language=Chinese|chapter=62|title-link=History of Liao}}</ref> It became more widely used in the [[Song dynasty]] under [[Emperor Renzong of Song|Emperor Renzong]] and [[Emperor Shenzong of Song|Emperor Shenzong]].
Another early proposal for abolishing ''lingchi'' was submitted by [[Lu You]] (1125–1210) in a memorandum to the imperial court of the [[Song dynasty|Southern Song dynasty]]. Lu You's elaborate argument against ''lingchi'' was piously copied and transmitted by generations of scholars, among them influential jurists of all dynasties, until the late Qing dynasty reformist [[Shen Jiaben]] (1840–1913) included it in his 1905 memorandum that obtained the abolition. This anti-''lingchi'' trend coincided with a more general attitude opposed to "cruel and unusual" punishments (such as the exposure of the head) that the Tang dynasty had not included in the canonic table of the [[Five Punishments]], which defined the legal ways of punishing crime. Hence the abolitionist trend is deeply ingrained in the Chinese legal tradition, rather than being purely derived from Western influences.
Under later emperors, ''lingchi'' was reserved for only the most heinous acts, such as treason,<ref>{{cite book|author=Zhang, Tingyu|authorlink1=Zhang Tingyu|title=History of Ming|date=1739|location=China|language=Chinese|chapter=54|title-link=History of Ming}}</ref><ref>[http://www.peacehall.com/cgi-bin/news/gb_display/print_version.cgi?art=/gb/pubvp/2006/03&link=200603030452.shtml 清华大学教授刘书林——中国第一汉奸曾国藩] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070813154736/http://www.peacehall.com/cgi-bin/news/gb_display/print_version.cgi?art=%2Fgb%2Fpubvp%2F2006%2F03&link=200603030452.shtml |date=13 August 2007 }}</ref> a charge often dubious or false, as exemplified by the deaths of [[Liu Jin]], a [[Ming dynasty]] eunuch, and [[Yuan Chonghuan]], a Ming dynasty general. In 1542, ''lingchi'' was inflicted on a group of palace women who had [[Renyin palace rebellion|attempted to assassinate]] the [[Jiajing Emperor]], along with his favourite concubine, [[Consort Duan (Cao)|Consort Duan]]. The bodies of the women were then displayed in public.<ref>{{cite book| editor1=History Office | title=明實錄：明世宗實錄| language=Chinese | trans-title=Veritable Records of the Ming: Veritable Records of Shizong of Ming | url=http://ctext.org/wiki.pl?if=gb&res=309093 | publisher=Ctext | date=1620s | volume=267}}</ref> Reports from Qing dynasty jurists such as Shen Jiaben show that executioners' customs varied, as the regular way to perform this penalty was not specified in detail in the penal code.{{Citation needed|date=July 2007}}
''Lingchi'' was also known in Vietnam, notably being used as the method of execution of the French missionary [[Joseph Marchand]], in 1835, as part of the repression following the unsuccessful [[Lê Văn Khôi revolt]].
An 1858 account by ''[[Harper's Weekly]]'' claimed the martyr [[Auguste Chapdelaine]] was killed by ''lingchi''; in reality he was beaten to death.
As Western countries moved to abolish similar punishments, some Westerners began to focus attention on the methods of execution used in China. As early as 1866, the time when Britain itself moved to abolish its own cruel method of [[hanging, drawing, and quartering]], [[Thomas Francis Wade]], then serving with the British diplomatic mission in China, unsuccessfully urged the abolition of ''lingchi''.
''Lingchi'' remained in the [[Qing dynasty]]'s code of laws for persons convicted of high treason and other serious crimes, but the punishment was abolished as a result of the 1905 revision of the Chinese penal code by Shen Jiaben.<ref>Shen, Jiaben. ''Ji Yi Wen Cun - Zou Yi - Shan Chu Lü Li Nei Zhong Fa Zhe'' (寄簃文存·奏議·刪除律例內重法折).</ref><ref>{{cite book|author=Zhao, Erxun|authorlink1=Zhao Erxun|title=Draft History of Qing|date=1928|location=China|language=Chinese|chapter=118|title-link=Draft History of Qing}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|first1=Jerome|last1=Bourgon|first2=Muriel|last2=Detrie|first3=Regis|last3=Poulet|url=http://turandot.chineselegalculture.org/Essay.php?ID=22|title=Turandot: Chinese Torture / Supplice chinois|publisher=CNRS|date=11 February 2004|accessdate=30 July 2009}}</ref>
==Published accounts== * [[Sir Henry Norman, 1st Baronet|Sir Henry Norman]], ''The People and Politics of the Far East'' (1895). Norman was a widely travelled writer and photographer whose collection is now owned by the [[University of Cambridge]]. Norman gives an eyewitness account of various physical punishments and tortures inflicted in a magistrate's court (''[[yamen]]'') and of the execution by beheading of 15 men. He gives the following graphic account of a ''lingchi'' execution but does not claim to have witnessed such an execution himself. "[The executioner] grasping handfuls from the fleshy parts of the body such as the thighs and breasts slices them away... the limbs are cut off piecemeal at the wrists and ankles, the elbows and knees, shoulders and hips. Finally the condemned is stabbed to the heart and the head is cut off."<ref>[http://turandot.chineselegalculture.org/Textual.php?ID=3&CF=2&Fa=5 Turandot: Chinese Torture/Supplice chinois]. CNRS. Retrieved 20 May 2012.</ref> * [[George Ernest Morrison]], ''An Australian in China'' (1895) differs from some other reports in stating that most ''lingchi'' mutilations are in fact made [[post-mortem]]. Morrison wrote his description based on an account related by a claimed eyewitness: "The prisoner is tied to a rude cross: he is invariably deeply under the influence of [[opium]]. The executioner, standing before him, with a sharp sword makes two quick incisions above the eyebrows, and draws down the portion of skin over each eye, then he makes two more quick incisions across the breast, and in the next moment he pierces the heart, and death is instantaneous. Then he cuts the body in pieces; and the degradation consists in the fragmentary shape in which the prisoner has to appear in heaven."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pratyeka.org/books/australian-in-china/|title=An Australian in China|publisher=Pratyeka|date=25 August 2002|accessdate=30 July 2009}}</ref> * Tienstin ([[Tianjin]]), ''The China Year Book'' (1927), p. 1401, contains contemporary reports from fighting in [[Guangzhou]] (Canton) between the [[Nationalist government|Nanjing government]] and [[Communist Party of China|Communist]] forces. Stories of various atrocities are related, including accounts of ''lingchi''. There is no mention of opium, and these cases appear to be government propaganda. * ''[[The Times]]'', (9 December 1927), a journalist reported from the city of Guangzhou (Canton) that the Communists were targeting Christian priests and that "It was announced that Father Wong was to be publicly executed by the slicing process." * [[George Roerich]], "Trails to Inmost Asia" (1931), p . 119, relates the story of the assassination of Yang Tseng-hsin, Governor of [[Xinjiang|Sinkiang]] in July 1928, by the bodyguard of his foreign minister Fan Yao-han. Fan was seized, and he and his daughter were both executed by ''lingchi'', the minister made to watch his daughter's execution first. Roerich was not an eyewitness to this event, having already returned to India by the date of the execution. * [[George Ryley Scott]], ''History of Torture'' (1940) claims that many were executed this way by the Chinese Communist insurgents; he cites claims made by the Nanking government in 1927. It is perhaps uncertain whether these claims were anti-communist propaganda. Scott also uses the term "the slicing process" and differentiates between the different types of execution in different parts of the country. There is no mention of opium. Riley's book contains a picture of a sliced corpse (with no mark to the heart) that was killed in Guangzhou (Canton) in 1927. It gives no indication of whether the slicing was done post-mortem. Scott claims it was common for the relatives of the condemned to bribe the executioner to kill the condemned before the slicing procedure began.
===Photographs=== The first Western photographs of ''lingchi'' were taken in 1890 by William Arthur Curtis of Kentucky in [[Guangzhou]] (Canton).<ref>{{cite web|first1=Jerome|last1=Bourgon|first2=Muriel|last2=Detrie|first3=Regis|last3=Poulet|url=http://turandot.chineselegalculture.org/Essay.php?ID=3|title=Turandot: Chinese Torture/Supplice chinois|publisher=CNRS|accessdate=30 July 2009}}</ref>
French soldiers stationed in [[Beijing]] had the opportunity to photograph three different ''lingchi'' executions in 1905: * Wang Weiqin (王維勤), a former official who killed two families, executed on 31 October 1904.<ref name=Bourgon2004ID8>{{cite web|editor-last=Bourgon|editor-first=Jérôme|title=Exécution de Wang Weiqin|trans-title=Execution of Wan Weiqin|url=http://turandot.chineselegalculture.org/Event.php?ID=8|date=2004|website=Chinese Torture - Supplices Chinois|publisher=IAO: Institut d'Asie Orientale|language=English, French|accessdate=25 May 2015}}</ref><ref>{{Citation|title=Essay|url=http://turandot.chineselegalculture.org/Essay.php?ID=11}}</ref> * Unknown, reason unknown, possibly a young deranged boy who killed his mother, and was executed in January 1905. Photographs were published in various volumes of Georges Dumas' ''Nouveau traité de psychologie'', 8 vols., Paris, 1930–43<!-- (but not in Dumas' 1923 Traité de psychologie!) -->, and again nominally by Bataille (in fact by Lo Duca), who mistakenly appended abstracts of Fou-tchou-li's executions as related by Carpeaux (see below).<ref>{{Citation|title=The complete set|url=http://turandot.chineselegalculture.org/Event.php?ID=10}}</ref> * Fou-tchou-li or Fuzhuli (符珠哩),<ref>[http://turandot.chineselegalculture.org/Event.php?ID=1 Turandot: Chinese Torture/Supplice chinois]. CNRS. Retrieved 20 May 2012.</ref> a Mongol guard who killed his master, the Prince of the [[Aohan Banner|Aohan]] [[Banners of Inner Mongolia|Banner]] of [[Inner Mongolia]], and who was executed on 10 April 1905; as ''lingchi'' was to be abolished two weeks later, this was presumably the last attested case of ''lingchi'' in Chinese history,<ref>{{cite web|first1=Jerome|last1=Bourgon|first2=Muriel|last2=Detrie|first3=Regis|last3=Poulet|url=http://turandot.chineselegalculture.org/Event.php?ID=1|title=Complete set|publisher=CNRS|accessdate=30 July 2009}}</ref> or said Kang Xiaoba (康小八)<ref>[http://data.tv.sohu.com/movie/data/24054/ 史学研究向下延伸的道路能走多久mm读《狼烟北平》有感]. Sohu. Retrieved 20 May 2012. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110716102545/http://data.tv.sohu.com/movie/data/24054/ |date=16 July 2011 }}</ref> Photographs appeared in books by Matignon (1910), and Carpeaux (1913), the latter claiming (falsely) that he was present.{{Citation needed|date=June 2007}} Carpeaux's narrative was mistakenly, but persistently, associated with photographs published by Dumas and Bataille. Even related to the correct set of photos, Carpeaux's narrative is highly dubious; for instance, an examination of the Chinese judicial archives show that Carpeaux bluntly invented the execution decree. The proclamation is reported to state: "The Mongolian princes demand that the aforesaid Fou-Tchou-Le, guilty of the murder of Prince Ao-Han-Ouan, be burned alive, but the Emperor finds this torture too cruel and condemns Fou-Tchou-Li to slow death by ''leng-tch-e'' (different spelling of ''lingchi'', cutting into pieces)."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.va.com.au/parallel/x1/journal/lmw/coup.html|title=Journal: coup de grâce (#1)|first=Linda Marie|last=Walker|publisher=VA|accessdate=30 July 2009}}</ref>
Photographic material and other sources are available online at the Chinese Torture Database (Iconographic, Historical and Literary Approaches of an Exotic Representation) hosted by the Institut d'Asie Orientale ([[CNRS]], France).<ref>{{cite web|first1=Jerome|last1=Bourgon|first2=Muriel|last2=Detrie|first3=Regis|last3=Poulet|url=http://turandot.chineselegalculture.org/|title=Turandot: Chinese Torture/Supplice chinois|publisher=CNRS|accessdate=30 July 2009}}</ref>
==In popular culture== {{In popular culture|date=August 2017}} Accounts of ''lingchi'' or the extant photographs have inspired or referenced in numerous artistic, literary, and cinematic media. Some works have attempted to put the process in a historical context; others, possibly due to the scarcity of detailed historical information, have attempted to extrapolate the details or present innovations of method that may be products of an author's creative license. Some of these descriptions may have influenced modern public perceptions of the historic practice.
===Non-fiction=== [[Susan Sontag]] mentions the 1905 case in ''Regarding the Pain of Others'' (2003). One reviewer wrote that though Sontag includes no photographs in her book – a volume about photography – "she does tantalisingly describe a photograph that obsessed the philosopher [[Georges Bataille]], in which a Chinese criminal, while being chopped up and slowly [[flaying|flayed]] by executioners, rolls his eyes heavenwards in [[transcendence (philosophy)|transcendent]] bliss."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://books.guardian.co.uk/reviews/politicsphilosophyandsociety/0%2C6121%2C1011239%2C00.html|title=Observer review: Regarding the Pain of Others by Susan Sontag|publisher=The Guardian|date=3 August 2003|accessdate=30 July 2009|location=London|first=Peter|last=Conrad}}</ref>
The philosopher [[Georges Bataille]] wrote about ''lingchi'' in ''L'expérience intérieure'' (1943) and in ''Le coupable'' (1944). He included five pictures in his ''The Tears of Eros'' (1961; translated into English and published by [[City Lights Bookstore|City Lights]] in 1989).<ref>{{Citation|url=http://www.jcrt.org/archives/04.3/york.pdf|first=David|last=York|title=Flesh And Consciousness: George Bataille and the Dionysian|journal=JCRT|date=August 2003}}.</ref> Historians [[Timothy Brook (historian)|Timothy Brook]], Jérome Bourgon and Gregory Blue, criticised Bataille for his language, mistakes and dubious content.<ref>{{cite web|first1=Jerome|last1=Bourgon|first2=Muriel|last2=Detrie|first3=Regis|last3=Poulet|url=http://turandot.chineselegalculture.org/Essay.php?ID=27|title=Turandot: Chinese Torture/Supplice chinois|publisher=CNRS|accessdate=30 July 2009}}.</ref><ref>{{Citation|chapter=6. George Bataille's Interpretation|author1-link=Timothy Brook (historian)|first1=Timothy|last1=Brook|first2=Jérome|last2=Bourgon|first3=Gregory|last3=Blue|title=Death by a Thousand Cuts|place=Cambridge, MA|publisher=Harvard University Press|year=2008|pages=222–42|title-link=Death by a Thousand Cuts (book)}}.</ref>
===Literature=== The "death by a thousand cuts" with reference to China is also mentioned in [[Malcolm Bosse]]'s novel ''The Examination'', [[Amy Tan]]'s novel ''[[The Joy Luck Club (novel)|The Joy Luck Club]]'', and [[Robert van Gulik]]'s ''[[Judge Dee]]'' novels. The 1905 photos are mentioned in [[Thomas Harris]]' novel ''[[Hannibal (Harris novel)|Hannibal]]''<ref>{{Citation|url=http://hannibal.hannotations.com/hannibal1.html|title=Hannibal|chapter=Section I|publisher=Hannotations|accessdate=30 July 2009}}</ref> and in [[Julio Cortázar]]'s novel ''[[Hopscotch (Cortázar novel)|Hopscotch]]''.
===Film=== Inspired by the 1905 photos, Chinese artist Chen Chien-jen created a 25-minute film called ''Lingchi'', which has generated some controversy.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://icwirral.icnetwork.co.uk/entertainment/newsandreviews/tm_objectid=15700731&method=full&siteid=50061&headline=could-you-look-away-from-the-death-of-a-thousand-cuts--name_page.html |title=WirralNews |publisher=IC network |accessdate=30 July 2009 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060317122730/http://icwirral.icnetwork.co.uk/entertainment/newsandreviews/tm_objectid%3D15700731%26method%3Dfull%26siteid%3D50061%26headline%3Dcould-you-look-away-from-the-death-of-a-thousand-cuts--name_page.html |archive-date=17 March 2006 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
A scene of Lingchi also appeared on the film [[The Sand Pebbles (film)]].
==See also== * ''[[Death by a Thousand Cuts (book)|Death by a Thousand Cuts]]'' – a 2008 book that examines the practice of ''lingchi'' * [[Scaphism]] – a similarly slow form of torturous execution * [[Waist chop]]
