{{Hatnote|This article is about the son of the British Prime Minister Sir Winston Churchill. For the former prime minister's father, see [[Lord Randolph Churchill]].}} {{Use dmy dates|date=April 2012}} {{Infobox Politician | honorific-prefix = [[The Honourable]] | name = Randolph Churchill | honorific-suffix = {{post-nominals|country=GBR|MBE|size=100%}} | image = Cecil Beaton Photographs- Political and Military Personalities; Churchill, Randolph Frederick Edward Spencer CBM1585.jpg | office = [[Member of Parliament]]
for [[Preston (UK Parliament constituency)|Preston]] | alongside = [[Edward Cobb (politician)|Edward Cobb]] | term_start = 29 September 1940 | term_end = 5 July 1945 | preceded = [[Adrian Moreing]] | succeeded = [[John William Sunderland]] | birth_name = Randolph Frederick Edward Spencer-Churchill | birth_date = {{Birth date|1911|5|28|df=y}} | birth_place = [[London]], [[England]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|1968|6|6|1911|5|28|df=y}} | death_place = [[East Bergholt]], [[Suffolk]], England | resting_place = [[St Martin's Church, Bladon]] | nationality = British | party = [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative]] | spouse = {{unbulleted list | {{Marriage|[[Pamela Harriman|Pamela Digby]]
|1939|1946|end=divorced}} | {{Marriage|June Osborne
|1948}}}} | children = {{unbulleted list | [[Winston Churchill (1940–2010)|Winston Churchill]] | [[Arabella Churchill (charity founder)|Arabella Churchill]]}} | parents = {{unbulleted list | [[Winston Churchill]] | [[Clementine Churchill|Clementine Hozier]]}} | education = [[Eton College]] | alma_mater = [[Christ Church, Oxford]] | profession = [[Journalist]], [[soldier]] | branch = [[British Army]] | unit = [[4th Queen's Own Hussars]] | serviceyears = 1940–1945 | rank = [[Major (United Kingdom)|Major]] | battles = [[World War II]] }} '''Randolph Frederick Edward Spencer-Churchill''' {{post-nominals|country=GBR|size=100%|MBE}} (28 May 1911 – 6 June 1968) was a British journalist, writer and a [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative]] [[Member of Parliament]] (MP) for [[Preston (UK Parliament constituency)|Preston]] from 1940 to 1945. He was the only son of [[List of British Prime Ministers|British Prime Minister]] [[Winston Churchill|Sir Winston Churchill]] and his wife, [[Clementine Churchill|Clementine Churchill, Baroness Spencer-Churchill]]. He wrote the first two volumes of the official life of his father, complemented by an extensive archive of materials. His first wife (1939–46) was [[Pamela Harriman|Pamela Digby]]; their son, [[Winston Churchill (1940–2010)|Winston]], followed his father into Parliament. ==Childhood== [[File:Churchillwithsonandgrandson.jpg|right|thumb|250px|Randolph with father (seated) and son Winston, in the ceremonial robes of the [[Order of the Garter]]]] Randolph Churchill was born at his parents' house at Eccleston Square, London, on 28 May 1911.Soames 2003, p. 81The ODNB states that he was born in Bolton Street, Mayfair [Matthew 2004, pp. 637–38], which appears to be an error. In Vol II of his biography of his father (''Young Statesman'', p. 290), Randolph states that his parents had moved from Bolton Street to Eccleston Square in March 1909. His parents nicknamed him "the Chumbolly" before he was born.The meaning of the word is obscure. Randolph himself claimed not to know what it meant [''Young Statesman'' pp. 350–55] His sister Mary Soames believed that it meant "a beautiful flower" in North West India, or else was a Farsi (Persian) word for a fat, happy child.[Soames 2003, p. 81] Mary Lovell writes that it was an Indian word for a chubby, happy child.[Lovell 2012, p. 268]Soames 2003, p. 81 His father [[Winston Churchill]] was already a leading Liberal Cabinet Minister and Randolph was christened in the House of Commons crypt on 26 October 1911, with [[Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs|Foreign Secretary]] [[Edward Grey, 1st Viscount Grey of Fallodon|Sir Edward Grey]] and Conservative politician [[F. E. Smith, 1st Earl of Birkenhead|F. E. Smith]] among his godparents.Soames 2003, pp. 84–85 Randolph and his older sister [[Diana Churchill|Diana]] had for a time to be escorted by plain clothes detectives on their walks in the park, because of threats by [[suffragettes]] to kidnap them.Soames 2003, p. 99 He was a page at the marriage of [[H. H. Asquith|the Prime Minister]]'s daughter [[Violet Bonham Carter|Violet Asquith]] to [[Maurice Bonham Carter]] on 1 December 1915.Soames 2003, p. 157 He recalled the [[Zeppelin]] raids of 1917 as "a great treat", as the children were taken from their beds in the middle of the night, wrapped in blankets, and "allowed" to join the grown-ups in the cellar;Soames 2003, pp. 211–12 he also recalled the [[Armistice of 11 November 1918|Armistice]] celebrations at [[Blenheim Palace]].Soames 2003, p. 217 He went to [[Sandroyd School]] and later admitted that he had had a problem with authority and discipline. His headmaster reported to his father that he was "very combative". Around this time his nickname in the family was "The Rabbit".Soames 2003, pp. 220–23 Winston, who had been neglected by his parents as a small boy, visited his son at prep school as often as possible.Lovell 2012, p326 Randolph was very good-looking as a child and into his twenties. In his autobiography ''Twenty-One Years'' (pp. 24–25) he recorded that at the age of ten he had been "interfered with" by a junior prep school master, who made Randolph touch him sexually, only to leap embarrassed to his feet when a matron came in. At home, a maid overheard Randolph confiding in his sister Diana. He later wrote that he had never seen his father so angry, and that he had made a hundred mile trip to demand that the teacher be dismissed, only to learn that the teacher had already been sacked.Bloch 2015, pp. 89–90Lovell 2012, p. 334 He remembered that he and Diana returned from ice-skating in [[Holland Park]] on 22 June 1922 to find the house guarded and being searched by "tough-looking men" following the assassination of [[Sir Henry Wilson, 1st Baronet|Field Marshal Henry Wilson]].Soames 2003, pp. 267–73 ==Eton== Winston gave his son a choice of [[Eton College]] or [[Harrow School]], and he chose the former.Lovell 2012, pp. 352–53 Randolph later wrote "I was lazy and unsuccessful both at work and at games … and was an unpopular boy".Churchill 1997, p. 37 He was once said to have been given "six up" (i.e. a beating) by his house's Captain of Games (a senior boy) for being "bloody awful all round". [[Michael Foot]] later wrote that this was "the kind of comprehensive verdict which others who had dealings with him were always searching for".Foot 1980, p. 164 He once wrote apologising to his father for "having done so badly and disappointed you so much".Lovell 2012, pp. 365–70 During the [[General Strike 1926|General Strike]] he fixed up a secret radio set as his housemaster would not allow him to have one.Soames 2003, pp. 267–73 In November 1926 his headmaster wrote to his father to inform him that he had [[Corporal punishment in schools|caned]] Randolph, then aged 15, after all five of the masters then teaching him had independently reported him for "either being idle or being a bore with his chatter".Churchill 1997, p. 44 As a teenager Randolph fell in love with [[Diana Mitford]], sister of his friend [[Mitford family#Thumbnail biographies|Tom Mitford]].Soames 2003, p. 283 Tom Mitford was regarded as having a calming influence on him,Lovell 2012, pp. 355–56 although his housemaster Colonel Sheepshankshttp://archives.etoncollege.com/Filename.ashx?tableName=ta_chronicles&columnName=filename&recordId=1847 wrongly suspected Randolph and Tom of being lovers; Randolph replied, "I happen to be in love with his sister".Churchill 1997, p. 43 Randolph was "a loquacious and precocious boy".Matthew 2004, pp. 637–38 From his teenage years he was encouraged to attend his father's dinner parties with leading politicians of the day, drink and have his say, and he later recorded that he would simply have laughed at anyone who had suggested that he would ''not'' go straight into politics and perhaps even become Prime Minister by his mid-twenties like [[William Pitt the Younger]].Churchill 1997, p. 66Lovell 2012, pp. 352–53 His sister later wrote that he "manifestly needed a father's hand" but his father "spoiled and indulged him", and did not take seriously the complaints of his schoolmasters. He was influenced by his godfather Lord Birkenhead ([[F. E. Smith, 1st Earl of Birkenhead|F. E. Smith]]), an opinionated and heavy-drinking man.Soames 2003, pp. 267–73 Winston Churchill was [[Chancellor of the Exchequer]] from late 1924 until 1929. Busy in that office, he neglected his daughters in favour of Randolph, who was his only son.Lovell 2012, pp. 352–53 On a visit to Italy in 1927 Winston and Randolph were received by [[Pope Pius XI]].Lovell 2012, pp. 352–53 In later life "relations between Winston and Randolph were always uneasy, the father alternately spoiling and being infuriated by the son."Matthew 2004, pp. 637–38 In April 1928 Winston forwarded a satisfactory school report to Clementine, who was in Florence, commenting that Randolph was "developing fast" and would be fit for politics, [[barrister|the bar]] or journalism and was "far more advanced than I was at his age". His mother replied that "He is certainly going to be an interest, an anxiety & an excitement in our lives".Soames 2003, pp.267–73 He had cool relations with his mother from an early age, in part because she felt him to be spoiled and arrogant as a result of his father's overindulgence.Lovell 2012, pp. 352–53Churchill 1997, p. 66 Clementine's biographer writes that "Randolph was for decades a recurrent embarrassment to both his parents".Matthew 2004, p. 598 In what would turn out to be his final report on leaving Eton, [[Robert Birley]], one of his history teachers, wrote of his native intelligence and writing ability, but added that he found it too easy to get by on little work or with a journalist's knack of spinning a single idea into an essay.Churchill 1997, p. 53 ==Oxford== Randolph went up to [[Christ Church, Oxford]] in January 1929, partway through the academic year and not yet eighteen, after his father's friend [[Frederick Lindemann, 1st Viscount Cherwell|Professor Lindemann]] had advised that a place had fallen vacant.Churchill 1997, pp. 53–54 In May he spoke for his father at the [[United Kingdom general election, 1929|1929 General Election]].Churchill 1997, p. 55Soames 2003, pp. 242–44 Between August and October 1929 Randolph and his uncle accompanied his father (now out of office) on his lecture tour of the US and Canada.Churchill 1997, pp. 53–56Soames 2003, pp. 242–44 His diary of the trip was later included in ''Twenty-One Years''. On one occasion he impressed his father by delivering an impromptu five-minute reply to a tedious speech by a local cleric. At [[Hearst Castle|San Simeon]] (the mansion of press baron [[Randolph Hearst]]) he lost his virginity to the Hungarian dancer [[Tilly Losch]].Lovell 2012, pp. 359–63 Randolph was already drinking double brandies at the age of eighteen, to his parents' consternation.Matthew 2004, pp. 637–38 He did little work or sport at Oxford and spent most of his time at lengthy lunch and dinner parties with other well-connected undergraduates and with dons who enjoyed being entertained by them. Randolph later claimed that he had benefited from the experience, but at the time his lifestyle earned him a magisterial letter of rebuke from his father (29 December 1929), warning him that he was "not acquiring any habits of industry or concentration" and that he would withdraw him from Oxford if he did not knuckle down to study. Winston Churchill had also received a similar and oft-quoted letter of rebuke from his own father, [[Lord Randolph Churchill]], at almost exactly the same age.Churchill 1997, pp.63–65 ==Speaking tour of the US== Randolph dropped out of Oxford in October 1930 to conduct a lecture tour of the US.Lovell 2012, pp. 365–70 He was already in debt; his mother guessed correctly that he would never finish his degree.Soames 2003, pp. 267–73 Contrary to his later claims, his father attempted to dissuade him at the time.Churchill 1997, p. 70 Unlike his father, who had become a powerful orator through much practice, and whose speeches always required extensive preparation, public speaking came easily to Randolph. His son later recorded that this was a mixed blessing: "because of the very facility with which he could speak extemporaneously [he] failed to make the effort required to bring him more success".Churchill 1997, p. 72 Randolph very nearly married Miss [[Kay Halle]] of [[Cleveland, Ohio]], seven years his senior. His father wrote begging him not to be so foolish as to marry before he had established a career.Churchill 1997, p. 77 Clementine visited him in December, using money Winston had given her to buy a small car.Lovell 2012, pp. 365–70 Contrary to newspaper reports that she had crossed the Atlantic to put a stop to the wedding,Lovell 2012, pp. 365–70 she only learned of the engagement when she arrived.Soames 2003, pp. 267–73 She found Randolph, to her horror, living in an extravagant suite of hotel rooms, but was able to write to Miss Halle's father, who agreed that it would be unwise for their children to marry.Churchill 1997, p. 77 Clementine wrote to her husband of one of Randolph's lectures "Frankly, it was not at ''all'' good" and commented that he should have had it well-practised by now, although she was impressed by his delivery.Lovell 2012, pp. 365–70 She went home in April 1931, having enjoyed Randolph's company in New York.Lovell 2012, pp. 365–70 She would later look back on the trip with nostalgia.Soames 2003, pp. 267–73 Randolph's lecture tour earned him $12,000 (£2,500 at the then rate of exchange – over £140,000 at 2016 prices).Churchill 1997, p. 77[http://www.measuringworth.com/ukcompare/result.php Compute the Relative Value of a U.K. Pound] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160331194822/https://measuringworth.com/ukcompare/result.php |date=31 March 2016 }} By the time of his mother's arrival he had already spent £1,000 in three months, despite being on a £400 annual parental allowance.Lovell 2012, pp. 365–70 He left the US owing $2,000 to his father's friend, the financier [[Bernard Baruch]] − a debt which he did not repay for thirty years.Churchill 1997, p. 77 ==Early 1930s== In October 1931 Randolph began a lecture tour of the UK. He lost £600 by betting wrongly on the results of the [[United Kingdom general election, 1931|General Election]]; his father paid his debts on condition he gave up his chauffeur-driven [[Bentley]], a more extravagant car than his father drove.Churchill 1997, p. 80 In 1931 he shared [[Edward James]]'s house in London with [[John Betjeman]]. By the early 1930s Randolph was working as a journalist for the Rothermere press.Lovell 2012, pp. 365–70 He wrote in an article in 1932 that he planned to "make an immense fortune and become Prime Minister"Churchill 1997, p. 86 He warned that the Nazis meant war as early as March 1932 in his ''Daily Graphic'' column;Lovell 2012, p. 372 his son Winston later claimed that he was the first British journalist to warn about Hitler.Churchill 1997, pp. 88–89 In 1932 Winston Churchill had [[Philip Laszlo]] paint an idealised portrait of his son for his 21st birthday.it appears as the cover picture of ''His Father's Son'', Winston Churchill's 1997 life of his father RandolphBloch 2015, pp. 89–90 Winston Churchill organised a "Fathers and Sons" dinner at [[Claridge's]] for his birthday on 16 June 1932, with [[Douglas Hogg, 1st Viscount Hailsham|Lord Hailsham]] and his son [[Quintin Hogg, Baron Hailsham of St Marylebone|Quintin Hogg]], [[Robert Gascoyne-Cecil, 5th Marquess of Salisbury|Lord Cranborne]] and [[Frederick Smith, 2nd Earl of Birkenhead|Freddie Birkenhead]], the son of Winston's late friend [[F. E. Smith, 1st Earl of Birkenhead|FE Smith]].Churchill 1997, p. 87 Also present were [[David Beatty, 1st Earl Beatty|Admiral of the Fleet Earl Beatty]] and [[David Beatty, 2nd Earl Beatty|his son]], and [[Oswald Mosley]] (then still seen as a coming man).Lovell 2012, pp. 365–70 Randolph reported from the [[German federal election, July 1932|German elections in July 1932]].Churchill 1997, pp. 88–89 Randolph encouraged his father to try to meet [[Adolf Hitler]] in summer 1932 whilst he was retracing [[John Churchill, 1st Duke of Marlborough|the Duke of Marlborough]]'s march to [[Battle of Blenheim|Blenheim]] (Winston was writing the Duke's life at the time); the meeting fell through at the last minute as Hitler excused himself.Lovell 2012, p. 372 At [[Lady Diana Cooper]]'s fortieth birthday party in [[Venice]] that year a woman was deliberately burned on her hand with a cigarette by a thwarted lover, and Randolph sprang to her defence.Lovell 2012, p. 373 Randolph also became embroiled in the controversy of the February 1933 [[The King and Country debate|King and Country debate]] at the [[Oxford Union Society]]. Three weeks after the Union had passed a pacifist motion, Randolph and his friend [[Edward Stanley, Lord Stanley (politician, born 1894)|Lord Stanley]] proposed a resolution to delete the previous motion from the Union's records. After a poor speech from Stanley, the [[list of Presidents of the Oxford Union|President]] Frank Hardie temporarily handed over the chair to the Librarian and opposed the motion on behalf of the Union, a very unusual move. The minutes record that he received "a very remarkable ovation".Pearce 2016 pp. 390–92 Randolph was then met by a barrage of hisses and stink bombs.{{cite book|title=Barbed Wire Between Us: A Story of Love and War|author=Derek Round and Kenelm Digby|publisher=Random House, Auckland|year=2002}} His speech, facing what the minutes describe as a "very antipathetic and even angry house" was "unfortunate in his manner and phrasing" and was met with "delighted jeers". He then attempted to withdraw the motion. Hardie was willing to permit this, but an ex-President pointed out from the floor that a vote of the whole house was required to allow a motion to be withdrawn. The request to withdraw was defeated by acclamation and the motion was then defeated by 750 votes to 138 (a far better attendance than the original debate had attained). Randolph had persuaded a number of other former students, life members of the Union, to attend in the hope of carrying his motion.[[Jan Morris]], ''The Oxford Book of Oxford'' ([[Oxford University Press]], 2002), p. 375. A bodyguard of Oxford Conservatives and police escorted Churchill back to his hotel after the debate. Sir [[Edward Heath]] recorded in his memoirs that after the debate some of the undergraduates had been intent on [[debagging]] him.Heath 1998, p. 38 Heath wrote about Randolph with contempt, but went up to Oxford in October 1935 so was not an eyewitness Winston Churchill wrote praising his son's courage in addressing a large, hostile audience, adding that "he was by no means cowed".Churchill 1997, p. 96 Randolph's good looks and self-confidence soon brought him some success as a womaniser, but his attempt to seduce one young woman at Blenheim failed after she spent the night in bed for protection with his cousin [[Anita Theodosia Moira Rodzianko King|Anita Leslie]], whilst Randolph sat on the side of the bed talking at length of "when I am Prime Minister".Lovell 2012, pp. 365–70 Randolph, who had been lucky not to be named in court as one of her lovers, also comforted a tearful Tilly Losch in public at [[Quaglino's]] after her divorce in 1934, to the amusement of the other diners and the waiters.Lovell 2012, pp. 365–70 In the 1930s, Winston's overindulgence of his son was one of several causes of coolness between him and Clementine.Bloch 2015, pp. 89–90 Clementine several times threw him out of [[Chartwell]] after arguments; at one time Clementine told Randolph she hated him and never wanted to see him again.Lovell 2012, pp. 381–83 ==Early political career== Randolph Churchill's political career (like that of his son) was not as successful as that of his father or grandfather [[Lord Randolph Churchill]]. In an attempt to assert his own political standing he announced in January 1935 that he was a candidate in the [[Liverpool Wavertree by-election, 1935|Wavertree by-election]] in Liverpool; on 6 February 1935, an Independent Conservative on a platform of rearmament and Anti-Indian Home Rule. His involvement was criticised by his father for splitting the official Conservative vote and letting in a winning Labour candidate, although Winston appeared to support Randolph on the hustings.{{cite book|last=Gilbert|first=Martin|title=Winston Churchill, The Wilderness Years|year=1981|publisher=Macmillan|pages=123–24|isbn=0-333-32564-8}}Matthew 2004, pp. 637–38Soames 2003, pp. 267–73 [[Michael Foot]] was an eyewitness at Wavertree where he blamed Baldwin's India policy for hurting the Lancashire cotton trade. When he asked rhetorically "And who is responsible for putting Liverpool where she is today?" a heckler shouted "[[Blackburn Rovers]]!". "He collected 10,000 Independent votes in a few days and handed the seat on a platter to the Labour Party" as Foot later put it.Foot 1980, pp. 163–64 In March 1935, he sponsored an Independent Conservative candidate, Richard Findlay, also a member of the [[British Union of Fascists]], to stand in a [[Norwood by-election, 1935|by-election]] in [[Norwood (UK Parliament constituency)|Norwood]]. This attracted no backing from MPs or the press and Findlay lost{{cite book|title=Winston Churchill, The Wilderness Years|page=124}} to the official Conservative candidate, [[Duncan Sandys]], who in September that year became Randolph's brother-in-law, marrying his sister [[Diana Churchill|Diana]].Clark, ''Tories'', p. 542 He had a violent row with his father about Norwood and Winston did not support him in any way this time, although he was suspected by other Conservatives of having done so.Soames 2003, pp. 267–73 Duncan Sandys was the only one of Randolph's Conservative opponents to win; he soon became jealous when he joined the family and his father warmed to him.Lovell 2012, p. 385 Having blamed Baldwin and the party organization for his loss, he libelled Sir Thomas White. Over the summer he was summoned to the High Court to pay damages of £1,000; but immediately backtracked, when advised that without an apology a career in politics was over.16 July 1935, from a solicitor's letter to Winston Churchill, CHAR 2/246/108, CUCC Randolph Churchill was an effective manipulator of the media, using his family name to obtain coverage in newspapers such as the ''Daily Mail''. In the [[United Kingdom general election, 1935|November 1935 general election]] he stood as the official Conservative candidate at Labour-held [[West Toxteth (UK Parliament constituency)|West Toxteth]]; reportedly he was so unwelcome that they threw bananas.[http://www-archives.chu.cam.ac.uk/perl/node?a=a;reference=CHAR%202%2F246 CHAR 2/246/161 – CUCC], chu.cam.ac.uk; accessed 27 August 2016. The [[Edward Stanley, 17th Earl of Derby|Earl of Derby]] lent his support, and Randolph continued to aid the Conservative campaigning across the city.AR 2/246/116, Letter from Lord Derby to WSC, offering to help Randolph Churchill's election campaign in Liverpool West Toxteth. 23 Oct 1935 CHAR 2/246/117 He stood for Parliament a third time, as a [[Unionist Party (Scotland)|Unionist]] on 10 February 1936 in a [[Ross and Cromarty by-election, 1936|by-election]] at [[Ross and Cromarty (UK Parliament constituency)|Ross and Cromarty]], opposed to the [[National Government (United Kingdom)|National Government]] candidacy of [[Malcolm MacDonald]], but was defeated again.[http://www.leighrayment.com/commons/Rcommons2.htm Profile], leighrayment.com; accessed 12 March 2016. This embarrassed his father who was hoping to be offered a Cabinet position at this time.Matthew 2004, pp. 637–38 In September 1936, at his father's behest, Randolph pursued his younger sister [[Sarah Churchill (actress)|Sarah]] to the US in a vain attempt to dissuade her from marrying the much older comedian [[Vic Oliver]].Soames 2003, p. 276 [[Lucy, Lady Houston|Lady Houston]] had backed Randolph's three attempts to stand for Parliament. He was better backed financially than his father had ever been.Lovell 2012, pp. 381–83 This support came to a halt when she died late in 1936. Freddie Birkenhead remarked that he was "unbowed but bloody as usual". Thereafter he used his employment as a Beaverbrook/Rothermere journalist to promote his political career, and to warn of the dangers of Hitler. In 1937 he tried in vain to get an invitation from Unity Mitford to meet Hitler.Lovell 2012, p. 394 The diarist [[Henry Channon|"Chips" Channon]] speculated (15 April) that if Winston Churchill were to return to office under the new Prime Minister [[Neville Chamberlain]] the outcome might be "an explosion of foolishness after a short time", war with Germany or even "a seat for Randolph".Channon 1995, p. 119 Churchill warned the House of Commons (19 July 1937) that there were twelve-inch Spanish howitzers trained on [[Gibraltar]]. Channon recorded that this reduced the House's sympathies for [[Francisco Franco|Franco]], but that when the House learned that the source was "Master Randolph" (as he described him) MPs were merely amused.Channon 1995, p. 135 [[Virginia Cowles]] first met Randolph in New York in the early 1930s. He helped her to get a visa to report from the USSR in February 1939. She praised his courage but wrote of him that "going out with him was like going out with a time bomb. Wherever he went an explosion seemed to follow. With a natural and brilliant gift of oratory, and a disregard for the opinions of his elders, he often held dinner parties pinned in a helpless and angry silence. I never knew a young man who had the ability to antagonise so easily."Lovell 2012, p. 411 At a dinner at Blenheim for [[John Spencer-Churchill, 10th Duke of Marlborough#Marriages and issue|Lady Sarah Spencer-Churchill]]'s 18th birthday in July 1939 a drunk Randolph had to be removed after behaving badly to a woman who spurned his advances and starting a row with another man over Winston's reputation.Lovell 2012, p. 405 ==Military service: Second World War== ===Early war, marriage and Parliament=== Randolph Churchill joined his father's old regiment, the [[4th Queen's Own Hussars]], in August 1939.Matthew 2004, pp. 637–38Lovell 2012, pp. 413–15Churchill 1997, p. 168 He was one of the oldest of the junior officers, and not popular with his peers. In order to win a bet, he walked the 106-mile round trip from their base in Hull to York and back in under 24 hours. He was followed by a car, both to witness the event and in case his blisters became too painful to walk further, and made it with around twenty minutes to spare. To his great annoyance, his brother officers did not pay up.Churchill 1997, p. 176 On the outbreak of war Randolph's father was appointed [[First Lord of the Admiralty]]. He sent [[Captain (Royal Navy)|Captain]] [[Louis Mountbatten, 1st Earl Mountbatten of Burma|Lord Louis Mountbatten]], along with Lieutenant Randolph Churchill, aboard ''[[HMS Kelly (F01)|HMS Kelly]]'' (which was based at Plymouth at the time) to Cherbourg to bring the [[Edward VIII of the United Kingdom|Duke]] and [[Wallis, Duchess of Windsor|Duchess of Windsor]] back to England from their exile. Randolph was on board the destroyer untidily attired in his 4th Hussars uniform; he had attached the spurs to his boots upside down. The Duke was mildly shockedP. Zeigler, ''Mountbatten'', p. 125 and insisted on bending down to fit Randolph's spurs correctly.Lovell 2012, pp. 413–15 Randolph was in love with [[Laura Spencer-Churchill, Duchess of Marlborough|Laura Charteris]] (she did not reciprocate) but his mistress at the time was the American actress [[Claire Luce]], who often visited him in camp. He appears to have decided that as Winston's only son it was his duty to marry and sire an heir in case he was killed, a common motivation among young men at the time. He quickly became engaged to [[Pamela Harriman|Pamela Digby]]Lovell 2012, p413-5 in late September 1939.Soames 2003, p317 It was rumoured that Randolph had proposed to eight women in the past few weeks and Pamela's friends and parents were not pleased about the match. She was charmed by Randolph's parents, both of whom warmed to her and felt she would be a good influence on him.Lovell 2012, p418-21 They were married in October 1939.Soames 2003, p317 On their wedding night Randolph read her chunks of [[Edward Gibbon]]'s ''[[Decline and Fall of the Roman Empire]]''. Despite this she managed to become pregnant by the spring of 1940.Lovell 2012, p418-21 In May 1940 Randolph's father, to whom he remained close both politically and socially, became Prime Minister, just as the [[Battle of France]] was beginning. In the summer of 1940 Winston Churchill's secretary [[Jock Colville]] wrote (''Fringes of Power'' p207) "I thought Randolph one of the most objectionable people I had ever met: noisy, self-assertive, whining and frankly unpleasant. He did not strike me as intelligent. At dinner he was anything but kind to Winston, who adores him".Lovell 2012, p432 The polemic against appeasement ''[[Guilty Men]]'' (July 1940), in fact written anonymously by [[Michael Foot]] and others, was wrongly attributed to Randolph Churchill.Morgan 2008, p80 Randolph was elected unopposed to Parliament for [[Preston (UK Parliament constituency)|Preston]] at a wartime by-election in September 1940.Churchill 1997, pp. 196–97 Soon afterwards his son [[Winston Churchill (1940–2010)|Winston]] was born on 10 October 1940.Soames 2003, p331Lovell 2012, p436 During the first year of marriage Randolph had no home of his own until [[Brendan Bracken]] found them a vicarage at [[Ickleford]] near [[Hitchin]], [[Hertfordshire]]. Pamela often had to ask Winston to pay Randolph's gambling debts.Lovell 2012, p439-44 ===North Africa=== It was widely suspected, including by Randolph himself, that secret orders had been given that the 4th Hussars were not to be sent into action (they were, as soon as Randolph transferred out). Randolph transferred to [[No. 8 (Guards) Commando]]. In February 1941 they were sent out, a six week journey via the [[Cape of Good Hope]] and the East Coast of Africa, avoiding the Central Mediterranean where the Italian navy and Axis air forces were strong. Randolph, who was still earning £1,500 per annum as a [[Max Aitken, 1st Baron Beaverbrook|Lord Beaverbrook]] journalist, lost £3,000 gambling on the voyage. Pamela had to go to Beaverbrook, who refused her an advance on Randolph's salary. Declining his offer of an outright gift (it is unclear whether submitting to his sexual advances was a condition), she sold her wedding presents, including jewellery, took a job with Beaverbrook, arranging accommodation for workers being redeployed around the country, sublet her home and moved into a cheap room on the top floor of [[The Dorchester]] (very risky during [[The Blitz]]). By accepting hospitality from others most evenings she was able to put her entire salary towards paying Randolph's debts. She may also have had a [[miscarriage]] at this time. The marriage was as good as over and she soon began an affair with her future husband [[Averell Harriman]], who was also staying at the Dorchester at the time.Lovell 2012, p439-44 Once in Egypt, Randolph served as a General Staff (Intelligence) officer at Middle East HQ.Matthew 2004, p637-8 Averell Harriman visited Randolph in Cairo in June 1941 to bring him news of his family. Randolph, who himself had a long-term mistress and several casual girlfriends at the time, had no idea yet that he was being cuckolded. He had recently been reduced to tears on being told to his face by a brother officer how deeply disliked he was, something of which he had previously had no idea.Lovell 2012, p447-8 Later in 1941 he was promoted to the rank of [[Major (United Kingdom)|Major]] and put in charge of Army information at GHQ.Lovell 2012, p447-8 For a time he edited a newspaper ''Desert News'' for the troops.Churchill 1997, pp. 196–97 He lived at [[Shepheard's Hotel]]. Anita Leslie, then in an ambulance company, wrote that "he could not cease trumpeting his opinions and older men could be seen turning purple with anger" and that he was "insufferable".Lovell 2012, p447-8 On leave in January 1942, he criticised the Tories for exculpating Winston Churchill's decision to defend Greece and Crete. He was sensitive to the "co-operation and self-sacrifice" of parts of the Empire that in 1942 were in more immediate danger than the British Isles, mentioning [[Australia]] and [[British Malaya|Malaya]] which suffered under Japanese threats of invasion. He was scathing of Sir Herbert Williams' ''Official Report'' into the Conduct of the War.HC Deb 28 January 1942 vol. 377, cc. 727–890 His father, who was under great stress following recent Japanese victories in the Far East, visited him briefly in Cairo in spring 1942.Lovell 2012, p456-9 Randolph had a row with his parents so violent that Clementine thought Winston might have a seizure.Soames 2003, p352-3 In April 1942 he volunteered for the newly formed [[Special Air Service|SAS]], to his mother's dismay because of the strain on his father. She contemplated cabling him forbidding him to go, but knew that Winston would want him to.Lovell 2012, p456-9Soames 2003, p352-3 He joined the SAS CO [[David Stirling]] and six SAS men on a mission behind enemy lines in the [[Libyan Desert]] to [[Benghazi]] in May 1942.Churchill 1997, pp. 207–15{{efn| although the enlisted ranks of the SAS were made up of picked men, some of the officers were appointed on the basis of social connections, e.g. membership of [[White's]] Club. The same was true of the [[Royal Marines|Royal Marine Commandos]], in which Churchill's colleague [[Evelyn Waugh]] served.}} The Benghazi Raid did not reach its goals and Randolph severely dislocated his back when his truck overturned in a road accident during the journey home. After a stay in Cairo he was invalided back to England.Soames 2003, p352-3, 389-90Lovell 2012, p456-9 Randolph had sent few letters to Pamela, and many to Laura Charteris, with whom he was in love and who was in the process of getting divorced.Lovell 2012, p456-9 Evelyn Waugh recorded that Pamela "hates him so much that she can't sit in a room with him". By November 1942 Randolph had formally left her; his parents, who adored their baby grandson Winston, sympathised with Pamela.Lovell 2012, p456-9 In November 1942 he visited [[Morocco]] to witness the [[Operation Torch|American landings]]. Randolph encouraged the conversion of Vichy fighters to [[Charles de Gaulle|de Gaulle]]'s army, submitting reports to Parliament on 23 February 1943.North Africa, HC Deb 16 March 1943 vol. 387, cc 1033–37 In May 1943 Randolph visited his father in [[Algiers]], where he was celebrating the successful conclusion of the [[Tunisian Campaign]].Soames 2003, p373 Randolph, along with his sister Sarah, accompanied his father to the [[Tehran Conference]] in November 1943. On the way back they quarrelled again about his failed marriage, which may have contributed to the serious [[heart attack]] which Winston Churchill suffered at Tunis.Lovell 2012, p464-8 He visited his father, who was laid up with [[pneumonia]], in [[Marrakesh]] in December 1943 ([[Harold Alexander, 1st Earl Alexander of Tunis|General Alexander]] gave him a lift on his plane).Soames 2003, p381-2 ===Yugoslavia=== Randolph had encountered [[Sir Fitzroy Maclean, 1st Baronet|Fitzroy Maclean]] in the [[Western Desert Campaign]]. Winston Churchill agreed to Randolph accepting Maclean's offer to join his [[Maclean Mission (Macmis)|military and diplomatic mission (Macmis)]] to [[Josip Broz Tito|Tito]]'s Partisans in [[Yugoslavia]], warning him not to get captured in case the [[Gestapo]] sent him Randolph's fingers one by one.Lovell 2012, p469 He returned to England for trainingLovell 2012, p471-6 then in January or February 1944 he parachuted into Yugoslavia.Soames 2003, p389-90Matthew 2004, p637-8 Tom Mitford was also present in the group.Lovell 2012, p471-6 He was later joined in Yugoslavia by Evelyn Waugh and Freddie Birkenhead. Round about this time he lost a bet to read various books of the Bible without speaking, but never paid up.Matthew 2004, p637-8 After the German airdrop outside Tito's [[Drvar]] headquarters in June 1944 ("Operation ''Knight's Leap''" [[Raid on Drvar|Rosselsprung]]) Randolph was awarded the [[Order of the British Empire|MBE]], having been recommended for a [[Military Cross]]. Fitzroy Maclean reported highly of his abilities at this stage.Churchill 1997, p249 However, Maclean wrote of their adventures together, and some of the problems Churchill caused him, in his memoir ''[[Eastern Approaches]]''.Churchill 1997, p. 252 Tito had barely managed to evade the Germans and Churchill and [[Evelyn Waugh]] arrived on the island of [[Vis (island)|Vis]] and met him on 10 July.Churchill 1997, p. 251 In July 1944 he and Waugh were among the ten survivors of a Dakota crash. He suffered spinal and knee injuries. He cried when he learned that his servant had been killed, but behaved with "his usual loud rudeness" as an invalid.Lovell 2012, p471-6Soames 2003, p389-90 After discharge from hospital in [[Bari]] (in the "heel" of Italy), he convalesced with Duff and Diana Cooper in Algiers. His father visited him in Algiers on his way to Italy – they discussed French and British politics.Soames 2003, p389-90 Randolph was ordered by Maclean to take charge of the military mission in Croatia.Churchill 1997, p. 252 By September he was back in Yugoslavia, where Waugh recorded that he was drunk most days, needed to have things repeated back to him when sober and behaved awfully even when sober. Waugh described him as "a flabby bully who rejoices in blustering and shouting down anyone weaker than himself and starts squealing as soon as he meets anyone as strong … he is a bore – with no intellectual invention or agility. He has a childlike retentive memory, and repetition takes the place of thought. He has set himself very low aims and has not the self-control to pursue them steadfastly." Lovell writes that every observer, including Duff Cooper and Anita Leslie, record frequent "drunken ranting" from him at this period. On good days he could be excellent company.Lovell 2012, p471-6 With Waugh he established a military mission at [[Topusko]] on 16 September 1944.Churchill 1997, p. 256 One outcome was a formidable report detailing Tito's persecution of the clergy. It was "buried" by Foreign Secretary [[Anthony Eden]] (who also attempted to discredit Waugh) to save diplomatic embarrassment, as Tito was then seen as a required ally of Britain and an official "friend".Hastings 1994, pp. 268–91Stannard 1994, pp. 138–48Sykes 1975, p. 273 Tom Mitford, one of Randolph's few close friends, was killed in Burma in March 1945 when it was clear that the war was in its final stages.Lovell 2012, p471-6 ==Loss of seat== Randolph's attendance in the Commons was irregular and patchy, which may have contributed to his defeat in [[United Kingdom general election, 1945|July 1945]]. He had assumed he would hold his seat in 1945, but did not. (He never actually won a contested election to Parliament.)Soames 2003, pp. 423–24 Randolph had a blazing row with his father and [[Brendan Bracken]] at a dinner at [[Claridges]] on 31 August.Jenkins, p. 804 Many thought Winston Churchill's cronies Bracken and Beaverbrook, the architects of the general election defeat, reported this on 26 July 1945.Jenkins, p. 797 ==Second marriage== Randolph was divorced from Pamela 1946.Matthew 2004, pp. 637–38 His sister writes that after the war he led a "rampaging existence" as "he always had lances to break, and hares to start". He was loyal and affectionate, but "would pick an argument with a chair".Soames 2003, pp. 452–54 Winston declared that he had a "deep animal love" for Randolph but that "every time we meet we seem to have a bloody row". Randolph believed that he could control his temper by willpower, but he could not do this when drunk and alcohol "fuelled his sense of thwarted destiny".Lovell 2012, p. 496 His father no longer had the energy for argument, so reduced the time he spent with Randolph and the amount he confided in him. Randolph maintained good written relations with his mother, but she could not stand arguments and often retreated to her room when he visited. She was able to help him out of his financial difficulties, which he acknowledged, "spared him much humiliation".Soames 2003, pp. 452–54 As Winston Churchill's relations with his son cooled, he lavished affection on a series of surrogate sons, including Brendan Bracken and Randolph's brothers-in-law Duncan Sandys and, from 1947, [[Christopher Soames]], as well as, to a certain extent, Anthony Eden. All of these, Randolph loathed.Bloch 2015, pp. 89–90 He had still not entirely abandoned his youthful fantasy of one day becoming Prime Minister, and resented Eden's position as his father's political heir.Lovell 2012, po. 492–93 Randolph used to refer to Eden as "Jerk Eden".Thorpe 1989, p. 166 [[Noel Coward]] quipped that Randolph was "utterly unspoiled by failure". He was blackballed from the [[Beefsteak Club]] and on one occasion was slapped twice across the face by [[Duff Cooper]] at the Paris Embassy for making an obnoxious remark. He reported on the Red Army parade from Moscow. He was still trying to persuade Laura Charteris to marry him. Although they were on-off lovers, she told friends that Randolph needed a mother rather than a wife.Lovell 2012, pp. 492–93 In 1948 he tried to persuade Pamela to take him back, but she declined and, having converted to Catholicism, obtained a full annulment, soon beginning a relationship with [[Gianni Agnelli]].Lovell 2012, pp. 499–500 Randolph accepted that he could never have Laura, with whom he had been in love for much of his adult life.After Randolph's death Laura Charteris (1915–90) eventually married his cousin the [[John Spencer-Churchill, 10th Duke of Marlborough|10th Duke of Marlborough]] in 1972.[Lovell 2012, p.572] He courted June Osborne, his junior by eleven years. Mary Lovell describes her as "a vulnerable and needy girl-woman". They had a stormy three-month courtship, during which at one point June, high on a mixture of [[Benzedrine]] and wine, ran towards the [[River Thames]] and threatened suicide, calling the police and accusing Randolph of indecent assault when he tried to prevent her.Lovell 2012, pp. 505–09 Evelyn Waugh wrote to Randolph (14 October 1948) that June "must be possessed of magnificent courage" to marry him. On 23 October he wrote to June at Randolph's request,Churchill 1997, p. 288 urging her to see Randolph's good side, calling him "a domestic and home-loving character who has never had a home".Lovell 2012, pp. 505–09 Randolph and June were married in November 1948.Soames 2003, pp. 452–54Matthew 2004, pp. 637–38 Randolph's son Winston, then aged 8, remembered June as "a beautiful lady with long, blonde hair" who made an effort to bond with her young stepson.Churchill 1997, p. 289 Diana Cooper guessed at once after their honeymoon that Randolph and June were unsuited to one another. They had a daughter, [[Arabella Churchill (charity founder)|Arabella]], (October 1949 – December 2007).Lovell 2012, pp. 505–09 His sister later wrote that "He does not seem to have possessed the aptitudes for marriage".Soames 2003, p. 452–54 The marriage soon deteriorated and on one occasion he reduced Queen's Restaurant in [[Sloane Square]] to silence by shouting at June over dinner that she was "a paltry little middle-class bitch always anxious to please and failing owing to her dismal manners". Eventually another diner remonstrated with him for speaking to his wife in that way; Randolph rebuked him for interfering in a private conversation, only to be told that it sounded like a public conversation to him.Lovell 2012, pp. 518–23Churchill 1997, p. 343 ==1950s== [[File:Levi Eshkol-Vera Weizmann-Randolph Churchil1955.jpg|250px|right|thumb| Randolph Churchill (right) with [[Vera Weizmann]] and [[Levi Eshkol]] at the dedication of the Churchill Auditorium at the [[Technion]]]] ===Candidate for Plymouth and Korean War=== Randolph stood unsuccessfully for the Parliamentary seat of [[Plymouth Devonport (UK Parliament constituency)|Plymouth Devonport]] in [[United Kingdom general election, 1950|February 1950]].Matthew 2004, pp. 637–38 His opponent Michael Foot wrote that he talked as though Plymouth belonged to him, and issued "a brilliant cascade of abuse" in all directions, including his own party workers.Foot 1980, p. 162 Randolph reported on the [[Korean War]] from August 1950, six weeks after the initial North Korean invasion of the south. The American and South Korean forces were bottled into a perimeter around [[Busan|Pusan]] and [[Daegu|Taegu]]. His father gave him a handwritten letter of introduction to General [[Douglas MacArthur]].Churchill 1997, p. 303 This was dangerous work: 17 war correspondents were killed, either by enemy fire or in air crashes, including the correspondents of ''The Times'' and the ''Daily Telegraph''.Churchill 1997, p. 306 Randolph was wounded on patrol near the [[First Battle of Naktong Bulge|Naktong River]].Churchill 1997, p. 303 Before seeking treatment he insisted on finishing his [[Copy (written)|copy]] and giving it to the crew of a plane bound for Hong Kong.Lovell 2012, pp. 505–09 Whilst dining in Hong Kong, he had an altercation with the restaurant staff, who then proceeded to get the manually-operated lift stuck between floors, and to "accidentally" get grease on his new white suit whilst hauling him out. While Winston Churchill was researching his biography of his father, [[Alan Whicker]], who had been Randolph's dining companion for the evening, confirmed the account which Randolph had given to his son at the time.Churchill 1997, p. 307 He returned to Korea to report on the [[Inchon Landings]], the liberation of Seoul and the UN forces' crossing of the [[Division of Korea|38th Parallel]]. He then returned to the UK for an operation (6 February 1951) on his wounded leg.Churchill 1997, p. 307 Mary Lovell records that repeated stories of Randolph's drunkenness, foul temper and financial difficulties date from this period. On one occasion, probably around this time, he became drunk and abusive in the first class cabin of a [[British Overseas Airways Corporation|BOAC]] flight and had to be put off the plane at the earliest opportunity (the incident was hushed up to avoid embarrassing his father). Evelyn Waugh visited him in hospital, noting that there was no sign of his wife June, and observed that he had thought his own life dull "but when I see the alternative I am consoled".Lovell 2012, pp. 505–09 Randolph was involved in an altercation on board a train at [[Nottingham]] on 22 February 1951. He was denied entry to the locked restaurant car by a railway employee, then later asked by the same man to leave the reserved seat in which he had been sitting. While he stood smoking in the corridor, the man (by Randolph's account) taunted him that he was "in the soup again". Randolph called the man "a bastard". At the next station Randolph was questioned by a plain-clothes policeman who had been summoned to board the train. The railwayman actually ''was'' illegitimate and he sued Randolph for slander, his lawyers arguing that it was "not in the public interest" for this fact to be revealed. The eminent barrister Sir [[Hartley Shawcross]] finally persuaded him to withdraw his lawsuit after eighteen months of correspondence.Churchill 1997, p. 308 He stood for Parliament for Devonport again in [[United Kingdom general election, 1951|1951]].Matthew 2004, pp. 637–38 In 1951, as in 1950, Foot and Randolph exchanged invective in public, but got on well in private, often meeting for a drink at the end of the day when Randolph had been deserted by his own party workers, with whom he had a poor relationship. Foot and his wife [[Jill Craigie]] would sometimes even escort Randolph back to his train.Morgan 2008, pp. 139–41 Michael Foot later said to one of Randolph's researchers: "You and I belong to the most exclusive club in London: the friends of Randolph Churchill".Churchill 1997, p. 292 Having lost every parliamentary contest he ever fought (he had got in unopposed in 1940), he was desperately disappointed not to be able to get back into Parliament as the Conservatives returned to power.Lovell 2012, pp. 505–09 ===Early 1950s: Winston's peacetime premiership=== In the days after the 1951 General Election, while his father was forming a government, Randolph amused himself by ringing up Conservative MPs who hurried to the phone on being told that "Mr Churchill" wished to speak to them urgently, assuming that they were about to be offered a ministerial position.Thorpe 1989, p. 152 During the post-war era [[Anthony Eden]] remained the Prime Minister's designated successor, yet when Eden married [[Clarissa Eden|Clarissa Churchill]] in 1952, Randolph could hardly contain his utter contempt for his cousin's new husband. He dubbed his ranting phone calls the "Eden Terror".Thorpe, Eden, p. 379 Randolph had long been jealous of Anthony Eden, and often wrote articles critical of him in the ''[[Evening Standard]]''. These articles helped to harm Eden's reputation. Eden did not reply in public, but complained privately to John Colville.Lovell 2012, p. 526 Randolph was a Gold Staff Officer at the [[Coronation of Queen Elizabeth II|Coronation]] in 1953.Lovell 2012, p. 515 In a speech at a Foyle's literary luncheon at the Dorchester in September 1953Churchill 1997, p. 317 Randolph, who "had had a few drinks" asked why a rich man like the press baron [[Esmond Harmsworth, 2nd Viscount Rothermere|Lord Rothermere]] (his former employer) needed to "prostitute" himself by printing details about the private lives of public figures, which Randolph described as "pornography for pornography's sake". Rothermere was not initially worried by this or the next speech.Lovell 2012, pp. 518–23Churchill 1997, pp. 318–19 Randolph repeated his accusation at the Manchester Publishing Association on 7 October 1953Churchill 1997, p. 319 and in another speech. His lawyer and Sir Hartley Shawcross had both urged him to go ahead.Churchill 1997, p. 317 When sober Randolph could still be excellent company, as even his mother admitted, and could even switch off his "temper" when told that lunch was ready. Randolph was assisted by [[Alan Brien]] to write the life of Lord Derby, and whilst researching it in 1953 he and June lived at Oving House near [[Aylesbury]], which got him away from [[White's Club]] and his gambling friends. The family trusteesThe Churchill family had become wealthy by the late 1940s, from the royalties from Winston Churchill's "History of the Second World War", which received very favourable tax treatment agreed to buy Stour House, [[East Bergholt]], near [[Colchester]]. For the first time he had a proper home of his own.Lovell 2012, pp. 518–23 However, his marriage continued to deteriorate, with occasional reports that he had blacked his wife's eye or that she had left to stay with friends, or that she had flung all her clothes out of a window. There was one furious row at [[Chequers]], described as "gruesome" by June and "his familiar rudeness" by Mary Lovell. He called his brother-in-law Christopher Soames "a shit" and Eden "a jerk" whilst his father, still Prime Minister at the time, was so "shaken with fury" that he seemed about to have a seizure. Randolph retired upstairs for a further noisy row with his wife, declaring that he would never see his father again. Sir Winston patched up the argument at 1am.Lovell 2012, pp. 518–23 June finally left him in the summer of 1954.Lovell 2012, pp. 518–23 Even on the eve of his father's resignation, Randolph told his cousin Clarissa Eden that he did not approve of her husband becoming Prime Minister.Lovell 2012, p. 526 Winston Churchill had declined a peerage at the end of the Second World War, and then did so [[Honours of Winston Churchill#Proposed dukedom|again on his retirement in 1955]] (when he was offered the Dukedom of London),Rasor, Eugene L. [https://books.google.com/books?id=6PpNUK5u1lkC&pg=PA205&lpg=PA205 ''Winston S. Churchill, 1874–1965: a comprehensive historiography and annotated bibliography''], p. 205. Greenwood Publishing Group, 2000; {{ISBN|978-0-313-30546-7}}. ostensibly so as not to compromise his son's political career by preventing him from serving in the House of Commons ([[life peers|life peerages]], titles not inherited by sons, were not created until 1958). The main reason was actually that Winston himself wanted to remain in the CommonsR. Jenkins, ''Churchill'' (2001), p. 896—but by 1955, when his father resigned as Prime Minister, Randolph's political career was "already hopeless". ===Late 1950s=== Randolph introduced his father to [[Aristotle Onassis]], on whose yacht ''Christina'' he was often to cruise, in January 1956.Soames 2003, p. 505 He set up a private company, "Country Bumpkins", to market his pamphlet "What I said about the Press" (in his speeches in 1953), which most newsagents refused to stock, and soon found himself involved in a libel case.Churchill 1997, p. 321 He was carefully briefed on precise details both of facts and of the intricacies of the law. He was very quick-witted under cross-examination.Churchill 1997, p. 325 His political opponent Michael Foot spoke on his behalf in court in October 1956, risking his own job on the ''Daily Herald''.Morgan 2008, p. 152 He was awarded £5,000 damages in 1958. His son writes that he had been "completely self-controlled".Churchill 1997, p. 328 In January 1958 June filed for divorce from Randolph. He fell in love with Natalie Bevan when she called on him, a case of the thunderbolt witnessed by [[Patrick Kinross]] who was there at the time. She was accepted as his companion by the Churchill family, visiting Chartwell, Hyde Park Gate and the "Christina".Lovell 2012, pp. 541–42 Although they became lovers in the late 1950s, Natalie remained married to her husband and never lived with Randolph.Churchill 1997, pp. 393–95 In November 1958 he gatecrashed a dinner in his father's honour at the British Embassy in Paris (Sir Winston was receiving the Croix de Liberation from [[Charles de Gaulle]], now returned to power in France); to general relief his mother, with whom he had not spoken in two years, addressed him as "dear boy".Lovell 2012, p. 544 In November and December 1958 Randolph published six articles in the ''[[Daily Express]]'' about the Suez Crisis. Soon afterwards he published ''The Rise and Fall of Sir Anthony Eden'' (1959). Questions were asked about it in the House, and Evelyn Waugh called the book "despicable".Lovell 2012, p. 544 [[Clement Attlee]] reviewed the book as "singularly offensive and inaccurate" and wrote that "Readers of this book will not learn much about Sir Anthony Eden, but they should get a full appreciation of Mr Randolph Churchill". Sir Winston was deeply embarrassed about the book: Attlee later told Eden that Churchill had told him that he should have made his review stronger, whilst Sir Winston told Eden that he saw little of Randolph these days and that whenever they met, as Eden recorded, "they only had a flaming row. Clemmie nodded sad assent".Rhodes James 1987, pp. 615–16 Eden's biographer [[Robert Rhodes James]] described the book as "a diatribe … best forgotten".Rhodes James 1987, p. 627 Since February 1959, as soon as it was clear that [[Nigel Nicolson]] was in trouble with his local Association, Randolph's open wish to be MP for [[Bournemouth East and Christchurch (UK Parliament constituency)|Bournemouth]] was the subject of much press talk. He was not shortlisted for interview by the local Conservative Association in May.Churchill 1997, pp. 376–77 This was his last attempt to enter Parliament; it had not helped his case that in Liverpool 25 years earlier he had said "I don't want to go into Parliament to represent a lot of stuffy old ladies in Bournemouth, I want to fight for really hard-pressed people".Churchill 1997, p. 371 ===Journalism=== Randolph inherited something of his father's literary flair, carving out a successful career for himself as a journalist. He edited the "[[Londoner's Diary]]" in the ''[[Evening Standard]]'' and was one of the best-paid gossip columnists on [[Fleet Street]]. He edited collections of his father's speeches, which were published in seven books between 1938 and 1961.{{cite book|title=Who Was Who, 1961–1970|year=1972|publisher=A and C Black|page=205|isbn=0-7136-1202-9}} Although he had no sentimental illusions about colonial peoples, he had no time for regimes based on supposed white superiority. He reported on [[Cyprus]] (where the British Army was fighting insurgents in the late 1950s) and [[Algeria]] (where French rule was coming to an end in the late 1950s and early 1960s). He particularly disliked the police state of South Africa, and on entering the country he was detained in customs for insisting on giving his thumbprint in ink (as a black person was expected to do) rather than signing the relevant entry form, until it was confirmed that he was entitled to do so. He obtained an interview with [[Hendrik Verwoerd]], who was surrounded by revolver-toting bodyguards after addressing a rally in Boer territory. He particularly abhorred the [[Sharpeville Massacre]], believing that "10 London bobbies" could have dispersed the crowd relatively peacefully.Churchill 1997, p. 382 ==1960s== ===Natalie and relations with parents=== In 1960 Randolph published the life of [[Edward Stanley, 17th Earl of Derby]] (described by Robert Blake as "a reputable if rather dull book" about a "dull man") to prove to the trustees of his father's papers that he was fit to write his official biography.Matthew 2004, pp. 637–38 In May 1960 Sir Winston Churchill approved of Randolph writing his life. "At last his life had found a purpose" his son later wrote.Churchill 1997, p. 392 [[Natalie Bevan]] declined his proposal of marriage in August 1960, but by then they had settled into a stable relationship. Winston Churchill (the younger) never heard Randolph have a row with Natalie Bevan.Churchill 1997, pp. 393–95 [[Jonathan Aitken]] and Michael Wolff were eyewitnesses to [[Bobby Bevan]] bringing Natalie over for the evening and waiting patiently downstairs while she and Randolph enjoyed a ''[[Cinq à sept]]''.Aitken 2006, pp. 36–37 His divorce from his wife June became final in 1961.Soames 2003, pp. 452–54Matthew 2004, pp. 637–38 The locals called him "the Beast of Bergholt" and he had a reputation for not paying small tradesmen. His researchers included Martin Gilbert, Michael Wolff, Franklin Gannon, Milo Cripps, Michael Molian, Martin Mauthner and Andrew Kerr.Aitken 2006, pp. 34–37 [[Jonathan Aitken]] first met him at [[Cherkley Court]], the home of his great uncle [[Max Aitken, 1st Baron Beaverbrook|Lord Beaverbrook]], where he was having a stand-up blazing row with the journalist [[Hugh Cudlipp]] who had made the mistake of criticising his father.Aitken 2006, pp. 33–34 In the early 1960s, after they had spoken together at an Oxford Union debate the previous evening, Randolph invited Aitken to drive him back to London and join him for lunch with his parents at 28 Hyde Park Gate. After Randolph had insisted on stopping three times for drinks on the way, they arrived late and with Randolph smelling of drink. Aitken beat a hasty retreat as Randolph had a blazing row with his mother whilst Sir Winston, then in his late eighties, turned red, shook his legs and beat his walking sticks together with anger.Aitken 2006, pp. 30–31 Winston Churchill's secretary [[Anthony Montague Browne]] recorded an incident on board Aristotle Onassis's yacht in June 1963, in which Randolph "erupted like [[Stromboli]]", shouting abuse at his aged father and a female diner who attempted to intervene, whom he called "a gabby doll". Browne wrote that "Nothing short of hitting him over the head with a bottle" would have stopped him ... "I had previously discounted the tales I had heard of Randolph. Now I believed them all." Sir Winston, too old to argue back, was physically shaking with rage, so that it was feared he might have another stroke, and afterwards made clear that he wanted his son off the boat. As he was taken off the next day (Onassis had got rid of him by arranging for him to interview the [[Paul of Greece|King of Greece]]) he was in tears, declaring his love for his father.Montague Browne 2009, pp. 299–300 ===Conservative leadership contest, 1963=== Randolph often reported on American politics, and in [[Washington, DC]] he often stayed with his former fiancée Kay Halle, who was by then an important Washington hostess during the Democratic administrations of the 1960s. Parties with Washington insiders were often enlived by his displays of what Aitken describes as Randolph's "boorish aggression and drunken bad manners". The American journalist [[Joseph Alsop]] stalked off from one conversation muttering that Randolph should entitle his memoirs "[[How To Win Friends and Influence People|How to Lose Friends and Influence Nobody]]".Aitken 2006, pp. 40–41 In October 1963 he was in Washington (where he phoned through the news of Prime Minister [[Harold Macmillan]]'s illness and impending resignation to President Kennedy). He flew home then travelled to Blackpool, where the Conservative Party Conference was in session. Randolph supported [[Quintin Hogg, Baron Hailsham of St Marylebone|Lord Hailsham]] for the leadership rather than Macmillan's deputy [[Rab Butler]]. He knocked on the door of Butler's hotel room and urged him to withdraw from the contest, stressing the sixty telegrams which had been sent to him in support of Hailsham, many of them concocted by his team at East Bergholt. He distributed "Q" (for "Quintin", Lord Hailsham's first name) badges, pinning them on people; he tried to pin one on [[Reginald Manningham-Buller, 1st Viscount Dilhorne|Lord Dilhorne]]'s buttock without his noticing, but accidentally stabbed him with the pin, causing him to bellow with pain. After talking to Jonathan Aitken, who was working for [[Selwyn Lloyd]] at the time, he put £1,000 on the eventual winner [[Alec Douglas-Home]] at 6–1 to countervail his bet on Hailsham.Aitken 2006, pp. 41–45 [[Maurice Macmillan]], [[Julian Amery]] and others were heard to say of Randolph's antics on behalf of Hailsham "if anyone can balls it up, Randolph can".Mount 2009, p. 264 He still hoped, somewhat unrealistically, for a peerage in Macmillan's resignation honours at the end of 1963.Churchill 1997, p. 390 In 1964 Churchill published ''The Fight For The Party Leadership''. The former Cabinet minister [[Iain Macleod]] wrote a review in ''[[The Spectator]]'' strongly critical of Randolph's book, and alleging that Macmillan had manipulated the process of "soundings" to ensure that Butler was not chosen as his successor.J.Harris, Conservatives, p. 504 Robert Blake wrote that Randolph was "blown out of the water" by Macleod's article (17 January 1964) and "for once … had no comeback".Matthew 2004, pp. 637–38 ===Final years and biography of his father=== In 1964 Randolph was laid low by [[bronchopneumonia]] which left him so frail he could only whisper. Later in the year he had a tumour, which turned out to be benign, removed from his lung.Lovell 2012, p. 556 His mother visited him frequently in hospital after his lung operation.Soames 2003, p. 534 Randolph and [[Evelyn Waugh]] had barely spoken for 12 years,Churchill 1997, p448-9 but they restored friendly relations that spring; Waugh commented that "It was a typical triumph of modern science to find the one part of Randolph which was not malignant and to remove it."Lovell 2012, p. 536Accounts of this incident vary. Mary Lovell writes that Waugh restored friendly relations after Randolph's bronchopneumonia [Lovell 2012, p. 556], whereas his son Winston wrote that Randolph was amused at the jibe and they reconciled over this [Churchill 1997, pp. 448–49]. At his father's funeral in January 1965 Randolph walked for an hour in the intense cold, despite being not yet fully recovered from his lung operation.Lovell 2012, p. 561 After his father's death, Randolph's relations with his mother, whose approval he had always craved, mellowed a little.Lovell 2012, pp. 563–64Soames 2003, pp. 551, 559 Randolph organised a luncheon party for her 80th birthday at the Café Royal on 1 April 1965. She often sought and took his advice.Soames 2003, pp. 551, 559 He wrote a memoir of his early life, ''Twenty-One Years'', published in 1965. Winston Churchill's doctor [[Charles Wilson, 1st Baron Moran|Lord Moran]] published ''The Struggle for Survival'' in May 1966. Randolph wrote to ''[[The Times]]'' criticising him for publishing within 16 months of his patient's death and contrary to the wishes of the family.Soames 2003, p. 557 Diana Mosley wrote to her sister [[Nancy Mitford]] that at least Moran had not told the truth about Churchill's children: "Randolph vile & making him cry" whilst Diana was being given electric shocks for hysteria and Sarah was frequently being arrested.Lovell 2012, pp. 566–68 Randolph never fully recovered from his 1964 operation.Lovell 2012, pp. 566–68 By this time his health was in serious decline. He had been consuming 80–100 cigarettes and up to two bottles of whisky per day for twenty years, far in excess of his father's consumption.Churchill 1997, p. 389 Drink had long since destroyed his youthful good looks.Matthew 2004, pp. 637–38Bloch 2015, pp. 89–90 Accompanied by Natalie Bevan, he often spent winters in Marrakesh and summers in [[Monte Carlo]], sometimes visiting Switzerland. His kidneys were failing, so he seldom drank alcohol any more, and ate little, becoming emaciated. Mary Lovell writes that "though he still behaved with the arrogance of [[Louis XIV of France|Louis XIV]] he was less explosive". Natalie spent the days with him before returning to her own house after helping him to bed.Lovell 2012, pp. 566–68 In 1966 Randolph published the first volume of the official biography of his father.Lovell 2012, pp. 566–68 He and his team of researchers carried on working on his father's biography despite his being mortally illAitken 2006, pp. 51–52 and it brought him fulfilment which he had not previously known.Lovell 2012, pp. 563–64 He had finished only the second volume and half a dozen companion volumes by the time of his death in 1968. Five volumes were planned (it eventually ran to eight, under the guidance of [[Martin Gilbert|Sir Martin Gilbert]]).Lovell 2012, pp. 566–68 In 1966 he signed a contract with the American politician [[Robert Kennedy]] to write a biography of his elder brother, President [[John F. Kennedy]], who had been assassinated in 1963.Aitken 2006, pp. 41–45 As a consequence, Randolph obtained access to the Kennedy archives, but he died before beginning work, the very same day that Robert was assassinated.[https://www.nytimes.com/1968/06/12/archives/grandson-to-finish-work-on-churchill.html "Grandson to Finish Work On Churchill"], ''The New York Times'', p. 50; 12 June 1968; retrieved 16 March 2011. ==Death== Randolph Churchill died of a [[heart attack]] in his sleep at his home, Stour House, [[East Bergholt]], [[Suffolk]] and was found by one of his researchers the next morning,Lovell 2012, pp. 566–68 6 June 1968.{{cite book|title=Oxford Dictionary of National Biography, Volume 11|year=2014|publisher=Oxford University Press|page=638|isbn=0-19-861361-X}}Article by Robert Blake. He was 57, and although he had been in poor health for years, his death was unexpected.Soames 2003, p. 559 He is buried with his parents (his mother outliving him by almost a decade) and siblings at [[St Martin's Church, Bladon]] near [[Woodstock, Oxfordshire]].{{cite web|title=Bladon (Saint Martin) Churchyard. Randolph Frederick Edward Spencer Churchill|url=http://billiongraves.com/pages/record/person/14040096#given_names=Randolph&family_names=Churchill|website=BillionGraves|accessdate=27 September 2015}} His will was valued for probate at £70,597 (just over £1,000,000 at 2016 prices).Matthew 2004, pp. 637–38[http://www.measuringworth.com/ukcompare/result.php Compute the Relative Value of a U.K. Pound] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160331194822/https://measuringworth.com/ukcompare/result.php |date=31 March 2016 }} ==Fictional role== [[H.G.
